member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreUpdateState
member.summary: Defines the various techniques the is using to take care of automatic updating.

item.description: The is currently not updating. Either because it has not been started yet, or it has been shut down.

The is auto-updating using an internal background loop and an available .
This state indicates that Awesomium is running in a UI context, where a message loop exists on the thread and a valid is provided by the runtime.
This state is usually temporary and the is switched to when a technology-specific WebControl is created. However, if an application only creates components though it is a UI application, the will remain at this state.

The is running in a .NET/Mono UI technology's context and is using a technology-specific timer or synchronization model for updating.
.NET UI technologies such as WPF and Windows Forms, provide their own , synchronization model and timers. Also, when used with Mono, certain technologies do not provide a standard .NET (such as Unity, Cocoa or Gtk), but they provide their own synchronization model and timers.
Whenever possible, Awesomium takes advantage of such available models and uses them for updating the , improving performance. For example, in WPF a special is used for updating the in intervals specified at initialization (see: ) or through .

The is running on a background (non-UI) thread and is executing its own update loop.
This state is used when Awesomium has been started from a non-UI, dedicated thread that has no message loop, using .
In this state, the creates and installs an Awesomium-specific synchronization context and starts its own updating loop that updates the core in intervals specified at initialization (see: ) or through .
When in this state, the users can execute code against the Awesomium API, using any of the methods described in the Interacting with Awesomium Cross-Thread section in the documentation of: .

Whenever possible, Awesomium takes advantage of such available models and uses them for updating the , improving performance. For example, in WPF a special is used for updating the in intervals specified at initialization (see: ) or through .

member.summary: The is running on a background (non-UI) thread and is executing its own update loop.
member.remarks:
This state is used when Awesomium has been started from a non-UI, dedicated thread that has no message loop, using .
In this state, the creates and installs an Awesomium-specific synchronization context and starts its own updating loop that updates the core in intervals specified at initialization (see: ) or through .
When in this state, the users can execute code against the Awesomium API, using any of the methods described in the Interacting with Awesomium Cross-Thread section in the documentation of: .

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection.#ctor(System.String,System.Boolean)

member.param: Specifies the path to the database file.

Specifies whether to store DateTime properties as ticks (true) or strings (false). You absolutely do want to store them as Ticks in all new projects. The default of false is only here for backwards compatibility. There is a *significant* speed advantage, with no down sides, when setting storeDateTimeAsTicks = true.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection.Execute(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Creates a SQLiteCommand given the command text (SQL) with arguments. Place a '?' in the command text for each of the arguments and then executes that command. Use this method instead of Query when you don't expect rows back. Such cases include INSERTs, UPDATEs, and DELETEs. You can set the Trace or TimeExecution properties of the connection to profile execution.
member.param: The fully escaped SQL.
Arguments to substitute for the occurences of '?' in the query.
member.returns: The number of rows modified in the database as a result of this execution.

member.summary: Creates a SQLiteCommand given the command text (SQL) with arguments. Place a '?' in the command text for each of the arguments and then executes that command. It returns each row of the result using the mapping automatically generated for the given type.
member.param: The fully escaped SQL.
Arguments to substitute for the occurences of '?' in the query.
member.returns: An enumerable with one result for each row returned by the query.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.Data.AsyncDataSource
member.summary: Represents a base that loads resources asynchronously.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.Data.DataSource
member.summary: Represents the base class for custom managed resource loaders.
member.remarks:
Local resources are requested using the asset:// protocol by default.
To choose the name of the protocol yourself, explicitly initialize the (see: ) setting .
This scenario allows you to override standard protocols (such as http://), or use DataSources to handle protocols that are not handled by default (such as ftp:// and mailto://).
Once assigned to a , a instance can only be used with that .
It can however be bound to more than one asset hosts, on the same .
You cannot dispose a instance, while it is assigned to a . Attempting to do so, will throw an .
A instance assigned to a , is usually destroyed internally when that is destroyed, or at .

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.Data.DataPakSource.FromDirectory(System.String,System.Boolean,System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a PAK file with the resources in the specified and returns a instance that loads all resources from the generated PAK file.
member.param: The path to the input directory.
Indicates if a an existing PAK file should be used, instead of generating a new one.
A list of file extensions to ignore (it is not obligatory to prefix the extensions with a dot ".").
member.returns: A instance that loads all resources from the generated PAK file, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic), if the specified does not exist.
member.remarks:
This procedure generates a PAK file in the specified , that contains all the resources in the directory (filtered by ).It then creates and returns a instance that loads resources from the new PAK file.
The generated PAK file, has the name of the specified .
If a PAK file with the directory's name already exists in the specified , it is silently overwritten.
If you specify true for , an existing PAK file (if any) with the directory's name in the specified , will be used instead of generating a new one. In this case, extensions specified in are ignored. Note however that the existing PAK file may have been created with a different filter (different extensions ignored) or before the contents of the specified change and may therefore contain outdated resources.
User must have read-write permissions on the specified .
This procedure fails silently by returning null (Nothing in Visual Basic), if the specified does not exist.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JavascriptMessageEventArgs.Message
member.summary: The message specified by the JavaScript caller, as the first parameter to a or call.
member.remarks: and allow callers pass an empty string for the message parameter. It is your responsibility to handle this situation. However this can never be null (Nothing in Visual Basic).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JavascriptMessageEventArgs.IsSynchronous
member.summary: Gets if the handler is called synchronously.
member.remarks:
This is true if a event is the result of a call and false if the event is the result of a call.
If this is false, you can still return a response to JavaScript clients through the property. The result will be passed to the callback function specified by the JavaScript caller as the second parameter to a call.
When is called synchronously, the view process is blocked until the handler returns. Therefore, you cannot make synchronous invocations from inside a synchronous , as this would cause a deadlock.
The synchronous call exceptionally allows JavaScript callers to pass certain kind of JavaScript objects to the managed application, that will be included in the array.
For details, read the documentation of:

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JavascriptMessageEventArgs.Result
member.summary: Gets or sets the result (returned value) passed back to the JavaScript caller.
member.remarks:
When a is the result of a call, the response is synchronously returned to the caller from the call.
When a event is the result of a call and is false, you can still return a response to JavaScript clients through the property. The result will be passed to the callback function specified by the JavaScript caller as the second parameter to a call.
If no is specified, will be returned from a synchronous call or be passed to the callback function specified by the JavaScript caller as the second parameter to a call.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.JavascriptRequestEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for a event fired upon requests issued by JavaScript clients through .

remarks.note: Applications handling , must explicitly set to true to let JavaScript clients know that the request has been accepted and processed.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JavascriptRequestEventArgs.RequestToken
member.summary: A token passed by the JavaScript client that can be used for a secure authentication of the request.
member.remarks:
This can represent any primitive JavaScript value other than Object. Management requests (such as ) are sent synchronously so that the native application can provide a response and therefore JavaScript objects (including JavaScript functions) cannot be passed to these requests. Any objects passed by a JavaScript client through any of these methods, will be replaced by .
Note that any string literal or other primitive values passed to the native application, are passed through IPC messages. Though wrapped to a native JSValue proxy, such data can be intercepted and therefore applications and native clients should optionally utilize an encryption they can both understand, to increase security.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.JSObject
member.summary: Represents an Object type in JavaScript. You can add, set, get, and remove named Properties and invoke named Methods.
member.remarks:
There are two major types of JSObjects, Local and Remote. Local objects only have Properties and can be accessed without error in the main process. Users can only create Local objects. Remote objects are defined within the V8 engine in a separate process and can have both Properties and Methods.
Method calls on Remote objects are proxied to the process and execute synchronously but may fail for various reasons (see ).
supports the Dynamic Language Runtime (DLR). This allows flexible coding, much similar to Javascript (which is a dynamic language).
Users can create a subclass of a to construct local objects with an interface that reflects standard features of the object. For details, read the documentation of .

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSObject.#ctor(Awesomium.Core.JSObject)
member.summary: Constructor implemented by inheritors to support restoration of a local that has been passed to V8, back to the initial managed type.
member.param: The remote that will be wrapped by an extended subclass.
member.remarks:
Local JSObjects created using the parameterless constructor that are passed to the web-page (either through a property or as arguments to a method call) are disconnected from the local instance and turned into remote objects. (Think of it as if local objects that are passed to the web-page, are treated as immutable value types the moment they are being passed.)
Any further changes to the local object after it has been passed to the web-page, will not be reflected to the remote object.
What's more, when this object is reacquired from the web-page, it is no longer the same local object that was initially passed, but a new remote object.
If local objects that are passed to the web-page were subclasses of , Awesomium.NET provides a way to automatically cast such objects back to their initial managed type.
Requirements: To support automatic conversion of custom local objects back to their original type when they are reacquired from a web-page:
The subclass of must be public. If it's a class member, any parent classes must also be public.
The subclass of must implement a constructor that takes one parameter of type . The constructor should call this base constructor.
For an example, see the Examples section.
Do not use this constructor to create a copy of a that persist outside a Javascript Execution Context (JEC). Objects created with this constructor inside a JEC, are still eligible for automatic disposal once the execution context is exited. Instead, use the method to create persistent copies.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSObject.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a JavaScript object.

remarks.note: Local objects can only have Properties and can be accessed without error in the main process.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSObject.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by the and optionally releases the managed resources.
member.param: true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSObject.Dispose
member.summary: Destroys and releases this instance.

remarks.note:
Remote objects are proxies of the actual objects, defined in a separate process within the V8 engine. Disposing them posses no risk to the actual remote object.
You should only dispose remote objects acquired outside a Javascript Execution Context or objects that have been cloned using . Wrapping your code with a using (Using in Visual Basic) statement, is the suggested technique. You do not need to dispose objects acquired inside a Javascript Execution Context.
For details, read: Javascript Execution Context.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSObject.Update(System.Int32)
member.summary: Rebuild the object graph, bottom-up.
member.remarks: Awesomium treats a local object as immutable passed by value. If a local object A has a property that has been assigned as value local object B, further changes to local object B will not be reflected to the object assigned to the property of object A. To resolve this in Awesomium.NET, local objects do not persist any properties to the native local object but instead they cache them to an internal dictionary. Only before the local object is passed to V8, we persist these properties to the underlying native local object, starting from the deep-most object to assure that the latest values are persisted. We use a depth limit of 12 which is similar to the one used by native Awesomium and it must be documented.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSObject.ToString

member.returns: A value representing the textual representation of the object.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSObject.GetPropertyNames
member.summary: Gets an array of names of this object's properties.
member.returns: An array of representing the names of this object's properties.
member.remarks:
When in a Javascript Execution Context, this property returns all properties owned by the JavaScript Object, including non-enumerable properties and properties of type Function (methods). To get a list of methods only, use .
as well 's indexer (), report both data accessors as well as function members while reports the existence of data accessors only and not of function members (methods).
's indexer (), will return a value in all situations. If a property does not exist it returns . Even if you try to implicitly cast the returned value to a or and the property does not exist or its value is not an Object or Function, the indexer will return a special invalid or that is equivalent to . When these are checked against null (Nothing in Visual Basic) they will return true and when converted to they are converted to false. Therefore it is suggested that you directly attempt to acquire the value of a property using the 's indexer () and then check the validity of the returned value, without a prior call to either or that both perform an unnecessary synchronous call to the child process.
implements and it allows you to enumerate the names of enumerable properties owned by the JavaScript Object. Enumeration only reports enumerable properties while will return all property names, including those not enumerable. For details, read: Enumerability and ownership of properties

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSObject.Bind(System.String,Awesomium.Core.JavascriptMethodHandler)
member.summary: Creates a custom method that returns a value, and binds it to a delegate.
member.param: The name of the method to create or substitute.
A method used to handle calls to the custom method.
member.remarks:
If the method exists already, it is substituted by the custom method. This allows you to bind standard methods of HTML DOM objects, to managed event handlers that are called when the methods are called from JavaScript.
Methods that return a value are called synchronously (the view process is blocked until the handler returns). Therefore, you cannot make synchronous invocations from inside a synchronous as this would cause a deadlock. For the same reason, no JavaScript objects can be passed to a that is called synchronously. Any such objects passed from JavaScript, will be replaced with in the array.
To create and bind to a custom method that is called asynchronously and does not return a value, use the overload.
For more details, read:
Introduction to JavaScript Integration
Custom JavaScript Methods
member.exception: This operation is only supported on valid and objects."
This operation is not allowed on an invalid (undefined) .

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSObject.Invoke(System.String,Awesomium.Core.JSValue[])
member.summary: Invokes a method with a set of arguments and returns a result.
member.param: The name of the method to call.
The arguments to pass.
member.returns: Returns the result of the method call.
member.remarks:
This operation is only valid on Remote objects.
Methods that return a value are called synchronously (the view process is blocked until the handler returns). Therefore, you cannot make synchronous invocations from inside a synchronous or as this would cause a deadlock.
To invoke a JavaScript method synchronously when using dynamic, all you need to do is make sure you use/cache the returned value, even if the JavaScript method is not expected to return a useful one.
For details, read:
Calling JavaScript Functions
Synchronous & Asynchronous JavaScript API

member.remarks:

supports explicit and implicit casting to all data types available with the Javascript Integration API.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSFunction.#ctor(Awesomium.Core.IWebView,Awesomium.Core.JavascriptAsyncMethodHandler)
member.summary: Creates a remote anonymous JavaScript Function object bound to a managed handler, that is called asynchronously.
member.param: The view on whose currently loaded web-page the function is created.
The managed handler bound to the created function.
member.remarks:
This constructor creates an anonymous JavaScript Function object in the global scope of the page currently loaded to the specified view, and binds it to a managed handler.
The created instance can only be used with the specified view, in any of the following ways:
Passed as an argument to a method of a remote object.
Assigned as the value of a property of a remote object, which actually creates a method and is equivalent to calling on the remote object.
Assigned as the value of a property of a local object, that is later passed as argument to a method of a remote object or assigned as value of a property of a remote object. This allows you to add methods to a local object, as long as this object will only be used with remote objects owned by the same view as the specified view.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSFunction.Bind(Awesomium.Core.JSObject,Awesomium.Core.JSValue[])
member.summary: Creates a new function that, when called, has its this keyword set to the provided value, with a given sequence of arguments preceding any provided when the new function is called.
member.param: The value to be passed as the this parameter to the target function when the bound function is called.
Arguments to prepend to arguments provided to the bound function when invoking the target function.
member.returns: A new that, when called, has its this keyword set to the provided , with a given sequence of arguments preceding any provided when the new function is called.
member.remarks:
The function creates a new function (a bound function) with the same function body as the function it is being called on (the bound function's target function) with the this value bound to the first parameter of , which cannot be overridden. also accepts leading default arguments to provide to the target function when the bound function is called.
The simplest use of is to make a function that, no matter how it is called, is called with a particular this value. A common mistake for JavaScript programmers is to extract a method from an object, then to later call that function and expect it to use the original object as its this (e.g. by using that method in callback-based code). Without special care, however, the original object is usually lost. Creating a bound function from the function, passing the original object as , neatly solves this problem.
member.exception: A null reference has been passed for .
The specified has been disposed.
The specified must be a valid remote object.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.JSFunctionHandler
member.summary: Represents a method that will handle calls to one or more custom Javascript methods, synchronously.
member.param: An array of representing the arguments passed to the method from JavaScript.
member.returns: A encapsulating the response that will be sent to JavaScript. This can also be a with custom properties.
member.remarks:
This delegate is used with , and in DLR to tell the to create a custom method that returns a value, therefore called synchronously.
The limitations of a synchronous handler are:
You cannot make synchronous invocations from inside a synchronous handler.
You cannot pass JavaScript objects to a synchronous handler.
For more details, read:
Introduction to JavaScript Integration
Custom JavaScript Methods
A method is always called in a synchronous Javascript Execution Context (JEC). Read this article for details about Javascript Execution Contexts.
To create a method that is called asynchronously, use the delegate.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.JSFunctionAsyncHandler
member.summary: Represents a method that will handle calls to one or more custom Javascript methods, asynchronously.
member.param: An array of representing the arguments passed to the method from JavaScript.
member.remarks:
This delegate is used with , and in DLR to tell the to create a custom method that does not return a value, therefore called asynchronously.
The benefits of an asynchronous handler are:
You can make synchronous invocations from inside an asynchronous handler.
You can pass JavaScript objects to an asynchronous handler.
For more details, read:
Introduction to JavaScript Integration
Custom JavaScript Methods
A method is always called in an asynchronous Javascript Execution Context (JEC). Read this article for details about Javascript Execution Contexts.

example.code:
Option Explicit Off
Private Sub OnDocumentReady(sender As Object, e As DocumentReadyEventArgs) ' Create a global object and assign it to a dynamic object. Dim myGlobalObject As Object = DirectCast(webView.CreateGlobalJavascriptObject("myGlobalObject"), JSObject)
' Make sure we have the object. If Not myGlobalObject Then Return End If
' Create and bind a custom method dynamically. In a dynamic expression, use ' the JavascriptAsyncMethodHandler delegate to create a Javascript method ' that does not return a value and is called asynchronously. myGlobalObject.myMethod = DirectCast(AddressOf OnCustomJavascriptMethod, JSFunctionAsyncHandler) End Sub
' Asynchronous JavaScript method handler. Private Shared Sub OnCustomJavascriptMethod(arguments() As JSValue) Dim webView As IWebView = DirectCast(sender, IWebView)
If Not webView.IsLive Then Return End If
' Access essential objects of the web-page's current JavaScript environment. Dim js As [Global] = [Global].Current
' We can have the same handler handling many remote methods. ' Check here the method that is calling the handler. If e.MethodName = "myMethod" Then ' Make another synchronous call. Dim res = js.window.confirm("Called from an asynchronous handler." & vbLf & "Do you confirm?") End If End Sub

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IResourceRequest.IsWindowOpen
member.summary: Gets if this is the first request sent by a new view that is the result of JavaScript window.open.
member.remarks:
The initial request () of new views that are the result of JavaScript window.open, is always issued before the event is fired.
By default, Requests that are the result of JavaScript window.open or are POST requests (such as the submission of HTML forms with method POST and target _blank), are not canceled. The user is expected to wrap the new view (see: ) when occurs, without reloading the target URL since navigation to the target URL is already queued on the new view.
In order to avoid double requests issued to a target URL, any other requests (most possibly links with target _blank or the submission of HTML forms with target _blank and method GET where data is passed through the URL therefore there's no danger of loosing data), are canceled by default, before , and the user must then load the target URL manually.
POST or window.open requests cannot be canceled in advance, as we do not know if the user chooses to wrap the new view (which is the expected behavior). This however can cause implications in certain scenarios (such as in a popup blocker scenario), where users may want to cancel such requests too.
allows you to implement an and cancel such requests yourself prior to , if you do not intend to wrap the new view at .

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.ThreadAffinityEnsuredAttribute
member.summary: Assign this to an executing assembly that hosts Awesomium, to tell Awesomium that code in the assembly is ensured to never attempt calling on Awesomium.NET API cross-thread, unless by using any of the available synchronization methods.
member.remarks:
Awesomium and Awesomium.NET are not thread-safe. Any call to members of the Awesomium API, should originate from the thread that initialized the or created the first , or technology-specific WebControl if is not explicitly called.
Awesomium.NET provides synchronization methods that allow you to safely access Awesomium API cross-thread. For details, read the Remarks section of: .
For API calls that are not Awesomium.NET-specific and need to be propagated to native Awesomium (using P/Invoke), Awesomium.NET performs several thread affinity checks whenever such a call is made. This ensures that no will occur, which is usually difficult to identify. Instead, if the checks conclude that the call being made is not thread-safe (does not originate from the correct thread), an is thrown with a clear message and stack trace.
Thread affinity checks are performed on each native Awesomium API call. This procedure may under certain conditions affect performance. If you notice performance cost and you are sure that you have carefully taken care of ensuring thread affinity yourself, you can apply this attribute to your executing (entry) assembly. This will tell Awesomium.NET to bypass most thread affinity checks.
Do not apply this attribute to your assembly unless you are absolutely certain that no illegal cross-thread calls to Awesomium are being made from your code.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebViewEventType.CreateSurface
member.summary: Occurs when an is requested by the view. Usually, every time the size of the view changes. You should return your own implementation here.
member.remarks:
When is called, reflects the previously assigned instance. If your surface is capable of handling resizing, you can keep on using the same instance on multiple calls.
When is called for the first time, returns the assigned to the view using or, if no instance has been previously specified, the default assigned to the view by Awesomium.NET. This is either a (for instances) or a technology specific .
If you are using an instance capable of handling changes in size, you should better use to assign your surface. This surface will be used with multiple calls of and it should be able to handle changes in size during . In this scenario, you can ignore the event.

member.summary: Occurs when the underlying web-view of a WebControlis about to be instantiated and wrapped or, for child views created in response to a , the native view assigned to the NativeView property of a WebControl, is about to be wrapped.
member.remarks:
This is the last moment for setting any of the following properties, on a WebControl:
Technology
Properties
WPF
Windows Forms
These properties are implemented as read-write properties on WebControls and can only be set before the underlying web-view of a WebControl is created, or a previously created native view is wrapped (see ).
Right after this event is fired, the WebControl goes live ( is set to true) and these properties can no longer be changed.
Attempting to set some of the above properties after a WebControl is live, is usually silently ignored but may also throw an exception. For details, refer to the documentation of the properties.
This event is not fired on instances. A component goes live immediately at creation.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebViewEventType.NativeViewInitialized
member.summary: Occurs when the native underlying web-view of a WebControl, has been initialized.
member.remarks:
This event occurs right after is set to true and also indicates the moment when global Javascript objects can be created. (See: )
This event is not fired on instances. A component goes live immediately after creation.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebViewEventType.WindowClose
member.summary: Occurs when Javascript in the page calls window.close.
member.remarks:
You can ignore this event, or respond depending on the current context. For example, if the page is open in the main window of an application or a tab, browsers display a confirmation dialog asking the user if he wants to acknowledge the page's request.
If the page is open in a popup window, browsers usually respect the request and close the popup window, without any confirmation from the user.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebViewEventType.JavascriptRequest
member.summary: Occurs when a JavaScript client sends a management request through (such as , etc.).
member.remarks:
The request sent is identified by .
A request token can be passed by JavaScript clients to the native application and it's received through
Unless the request originates from a page that has been created by the application (such as pages provided though a ), applications should be careful when handling management requests. For example, a command asks from the native application to exit immediately. The is provided so that native applications can validate such requests.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebViewEventType.JavascriptMessage
member.summary: Occurs when a JavaScript client sends a message through or .
member.remarks:
and the asynchronous , can be used instead of creating and binding to custom methods of a global JavaScript object created with .
Unlike regular synchronous custom JavaScript methods created by the managed application through or using the Dynamic Language Runtime (DLR), allows callers to pass JavaScript objects to the array, even though the method is called synchronously (see Synchronous & Asynchronous API).
JavaScript objects passed to are being serialized, any function members (methods) are stripped out and they are deserialized to the hosting application as local JSObjects. Nevertheless, the objects are still passed by reference. Any changes applied to passed objects in the handler of a event, will be reflected back to the original remote instances when returns.
Function members (methods) of objects passed to , are being stripped out when the object is passed to the hosting application (calling them from the hosting application would cause a deadlock). However this does not affect the original client-side instances.
JavaScript objects passed to , are serialized and deserialized using JSON. Objects whose structure includes a circular reference, cannot be passed.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebViewEventType.ShowJavascriptDialog
member.summary: Occurs when a JavaScript call that requires the creation of a modal dialog, is called.

member.remarks:
You should generally forward keyboard events to the active instance, whenever one of the following element types are focused:

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebViewEventType.ShowCreatedWebView
member.summary: Occurs when an creates a new child web-view instance (usually the result of window.open or an external link).
member.remarks:
occurs when an instance creates a new child view (usually the result of window.open, clicking on a link with target="_blank" or submitting a form with target="_blank").
It is your responsibility to wrap and display this new view in your application.
The event must always be handled in your application to wrap views created by Awesomium in response to users clicking a link or JavaScript window.open calls.
If you don't handle this event, the unused web-view instance will be immediately destroyed.
There are a number of facts you need to take into consideration, before taking the appropriate actions in response to a event. The following list presents these facts and some general suggestions:
The created child view, has the same type (see ) and is assigned to the same session (see ) as its parent (opener) view. Therefore, you should not attempt to set these properties if you are wrapping the new child view with a technology specific WebControl.
In order to maintain the relationship with their parent view, child views execute and render under the same process (awesomium_process) as their parent view. If for any reason the child process crashes, all views related to it will be affected.
If is fired as a result of a Javascript window.open, will be true. In this scenario, you should always wrap the created child view instance (), to maintain the parent-child window relationship (the child page can access the parent through the window.opener property; the parent can manipulate the child through the window object returned from the window.open call, which is why window.open was most probably used in the first place).
If is fired as a result of an HTML form with target="_blank" and method="post", will be true. In this scenario, you should always wrap the created child view instance (), to allow POST data be properly passed.
When or are false, it most possibly indicates that the event is the result of a user clicking on a link with target="_blank". Since maintaining a parent-child relationship is not important in this scenario, you should cancel the event by setting to true (this tells the core to destroy the unused web-view instance), then create a new (using ) or WebControl and navigate to the provided , if any. This allows you to take advantage of the isolated process architecture of Awesomium and let each view be rendered in a separate process.
Failing to cancel the event when you are not wrapping the new child view instance, will keep the native instance alive until the is shut down. This can result in numerous unused views being spawned, but never actually used.
When or is true, navigation to the , if any, is already queued on the created child view. Therefore you should not attempt to set the when you are wrapping the child view, as this would again break the parent-child relationship (window.opener on the child page and the window object returned from the window.open call on the parent page, will be rendered invalid) or prevent passing POST data to the server respectively.
Also note that since navigation to the , if any, has already started by the moment the child view is wrapped, will not be fired for the main frame of the new instance.
Navigation to the , if any, is blocked on the created child view, when and are false. As applications will generally choose to cancel the event and create a new instance to navigate to the target URL (or even choose to navigate to the target URL on the same instance that fired the event), Awesomium.NET does this to prevent false hits to the target URL, that would have occurred by the time the event handler returns and the unused child view instance, is destroyed. What's more, users may also implement and cancel requests to new views that are the result of JavaScript window.open (see ). Therefore, if your application chooses to wrap the created child view even though it is most possibly the result of a user clicking on a link with target="_blank" or navigation to the target URL has already been canceled by an (see ), you should in this scenario only, after wrapping the child view, set the property to to resume navigation to the target URL.
Applications can occasionally choose to wrap a child view even when is false or is true, if they want to apply a single process architecture where all new views created will be rendered by the same awesomium_process.
When is true, returns a valid, initialized instance. This may be initialized to default values if is false, or reflect the specs specified to the window.open call, if is true.
If is true, applications should generally wrap and present the native view in a new popup application window. This window should have the size and location specified in , if this is not empty. They should also respect the rest of the specs available through , when creating the new application window that will host the child view.
When is true, is always also true.
will only be true, if specs were specified to the window.open call. These can be standard specs such as width=400,height=400,menubar=no, only user defined, non-standard specs such as background=black or a combination of both. These specs are available through the property.
If only user defined, non-standard specs were specified to the window.open call, will be true. In this scenario, if your application does not recognize user defined, non-standard specs, it can ignore the value of all together and wrap the new child view in a regular new application window, tab or control.
When is true, returns an array of , representing the upload data passed to the using POST.
Finally note that only an empty name parameter or a _blank target attribute specified as the name parameter in a window.open call or in a link or form, will fire a event. Other target attributes (such as _top), passed to either a window.open call, a link or a form, are handled by Awesomium internally.
Several members of , may not return valid values if Javascript is disabled. For details, read the documentation of: .
Given the facts and suggestions presented before, if your application is about to wrap the created child view, the following table shows the methods available, to wrap the created child view using any of the Awesomium.NET web-view components:
Technology
Method and Notes
Core
Pass to to wrap the new view with a .
For windowed views (see ), you should now assign a . Offscreen views have a assigned by default but depending on your application's design, you may have to assign a new by either monitoring the event, or setting the property.
Resize the to match its container.
WPF
Create a new and assign to the property.
Note that you should assign the created child view instance to , before the goes live (see ), or else the will create and wrap a new, underlying web-view instance. The appropriate way to do this, is either by binding the property in XAML (see examples in the Awesomium.NET Samples solution available with the SDK), or by monitoring the event, the last fired before the control goes live.
Resize the or its container.
Windows Forms
Create a new and assign to the property.
Note that you should assign the created child view instance to , before the goes live (see ), or else the will create and wrap a new, underlying web-view instance. The appropriate way to do this, is either by assigning the property right after the is created (see examples in the Awesomium.NET Samples solution available with the SDK),or by monitoring the event, the last fired before the control goes live.
Resize the or its container.

member.remarks:
By default, technology specific WebControls provide their own drop-down (popup) menus. If you wish to prevent the control from displaying its own menu and handle the event yourself, set to true and then use any of the following methods to respond to the view:
These members are not directly available through the predefined wrappers. You will have to cast the wrapper to , to access these members.
Optionally, you can easily cancel or select an item by using: or .
The windowless , does not provide any internal implementation for drop-down (popup) menus. If you are using a instance with your UI application, you will have to handle the event yourself. Technology specific Awesomium.NET assemblies, provide predefined drop-down (popup) menu controls that you can use with your WPF or Windows Forms application.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.FrameEventArgs.IsMainFrame
member.summary: Indicates if this is the main frame of the page.
member.remarks:
When a page is loaded, the main frame usually finishes loading last. This is helpful when you want to know when a page is fully loaded.
While a specific page load may appear as complete, asynchronous requests (AJAX etc.) may still be in progress. The fact that the main frame of a page has loaded, does not guarantee that the visual content of the page is fully rendered.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.INavigationInterceptor
member.summary: Represents a service on a instance, that allows you to cancel frame navigations or add/remove navigation filtering rules to the view.
member.remarks:
You can acquire this service by calling on a instance.
Events on this service are called after the of a global assigned to , has been called. Returning true at will prevent the events of this service from being called. Rules applied to this service will also be ignored.
This events on this service are called on the I/O Thread. Therefore, you should not make any calls to instances and members that are not thread-safe.

Return Value

member.name: E:Awesomium.Core.INavigationInterceptor.BeginLoadingFrame
member.summary: Occurs when a frame is about to begin loading in the view. This event allows you to cancel loading the frame, potentially preventing navigations as well.
member.remarks:
When a page is loaded, the main frame is usually the first to start being loaded.
If is true during a event, it indicates a new navigation. When a with set to true is not canceled, an event is fired right after, allowing you to cancel the navigation.
Note that the event is called on the I/O Thread. Therefore, you should not make any calls to instances and members that are not thread-safe.

Setting
Behavior
If a url pattern passed to does not match a rule explicitly specified through , will return . This is the default behavior and it assures that only navigations that match any of the rules in the , will be blocked; everything else will be loaded.
If a url pattern passed to does not match a rule explicitly specified through , will return . This technique enforces the ; everything else will be blocked.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.Data.DataSourceRequest.IsWindowOpen
member.summary: Gets if this is the first request sent by a new view that is the result of JavaScript window.open.
member.remarks:
The initial request () of new views that are the result of JavaScript window.open, is always issued before the event is fired.
By default, Requests that are the result of JavaScript window.open or are POST requests (such as the submission of HTML forms with method POST and target _blank), are not canceled. The user is expected to wrap the new view (see: ) when occurs, without reloading the target URL since navigation to the target URL is already queued on the new view.
In order to avoid double requests issued to a target URL, any other requests (most possibly links with target _blank or the submission of HTML forms with target _blank and method GET where data is passed through the URL therefore there's no danger of loosing data), are canceled by default, before , and the user must then load the target URL manually.
POST or window.open requests cannot be canceled in advance, as we do not know if the user chooses to wrap the new view (which is the expected behavior). This however can cause implications in certain scenarios (such as in a popup blocker scenario), where users may want to cancel such requests too.
allows you to implement an and cancel such requests yourself prior to , if you do not intend to wrap the new view at .

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.DownloadItem
member.summary: Represents a download operation maintained by the .
member.remarks:
is a instance (therefore it implements ). This makes it ideal for use directly as a view model in an MVVM application.
An instance of is first created when the event is fired, to indicate that the download operation is about to start. The instance is added to the collection immediately after .
Developers can access the instance either through the event (see ), or through the collection ( implements ). For more details, read the following article: Handling Downloads.
Repeating a Download Operation Two instances are considered equal when the originating , and destination path (see ), are equal. This means that if you attempt to download the same file, from the same URL and save it to the same destination, Awesomium.NET will restart the old download operation instead of creating a new one. In this scenario there will be no change to the collection after the event if fired. What's more, will return the existing representing the previous download operation, with the values of all its members intact: For example, may be true and will reflect the number of bytes received during the previous operation. These values will only be reset after the event.
This behavior is useful for the following reasons:
If you are using the collection as a data source in an MVVM application, you wouldn't want a new item be created for a download operation that is actually being repeated.
The new (repeated) download operation, can still be canceled at by setting to true. Letting the members of the reused instance intact during , allows users to cancel the operation without affecting the appearance and behavior of the visual element bound to the reused instance.
When the download operation starts (immediately after ), the members of the reused instance will be reset allowing any bound visual element reflect that a previous download operation, is being repeated.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.NetError
member.summary: This enumeration contains a list of network errors.
member.remarks:
Ranges:
Range
Description
0-99
System related errors.
100-199
Connection related errors.
200-299
Certificate errors.
300-399
HTTP errors.
400-499
Cache errors.
500-599
N/A
600-699
FTP errors.
700-799
Certificate manager errors.
800-899
DNS resolver errors.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.NPN_NEGOTIATION_FAILED
member.summary: The request to negotiate an alternate protocol failed.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SSL_NO_RENEGOTIATION
member.summary: The peer sent an SSL no_renegotiation alert message.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.WINSOCK_UNEXPECTED_WRITTEN_BYTES
member.summary: Winsock sometimes reports more data written than passed. This is probably due to a broken LSP.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SSL_DECOMPRESSION_FAILURE_ALERT
member.summary: An SSL peer sent us a fatal decompression_failure alert. This typically occurs when a peer selects DEFLATE compression in the mistaken belief that it supports it.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SSL_BAD_RECORD_MAC_ALERT
member.summary: An SSL peer sent us a fatal bad_record_mac alert. This has been observed from servers with buggy DEFLATE support.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.PROXY_AUTH_REQUESTED
member.summary: The proxy requested authentication (for tunnel establishment).

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SSL_UNSAFE_NEGOTIATION
member.summary: A known TLS strict server didn't offer the renegotiation extension.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SSL_WEAK_SERVER_EPHEMERAL_DH_KEY
member.summary: The SSL server attempted to use a weak ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.PROXY_CONNECTION_FAILED
member.summary: Could not create a connection to the proxy server. An error occurred either in resolving its name, or in connecting a socket to it. Note that this does NOT include failures during the actual "CONNECT" method of an HTTP proxy.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.MANDATORY_PROXY_CONFIGURATION_FAILED
member.summary: A mandatory proxy configuration could not be used. Currently this means that a mandatory PAC script could not be fetched, parsed or executed.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.PRECONNECT_MAX_SOCKET_LIMIT
member.summary: We've hit the max socket limit for the socket pool while pre-connecting. We don't bother trying to pre-connect more sockets.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SSL_CLIENT_AUTH_PRIVATE_KEY_ACCESS_DENIED
member.summary: The permission to use the SSL client certificate's private key was denied.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SSL_CLIENT_AUTH_CERT_NO_PRIVATE_KEY
member.summary: The SSL client certificate has no private key.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.PROXY_CERTIFICATE_INVALID
member.summary: The certificate presented by the HTTPS Proxy was invalid.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.NAME_RESOLUTION_FAILED
member.summary: An error occurred when trying to do a name resolution (DNS).

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.NETWORK_ACCESS_DENIED
member.summary: Permission to access the network was denied. This is used to distinguish errors that were most likely caused by a firewall from other access denied errors. See also ERR_ACCESS_DENIED.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.TEMPORARILY_THROTTLED
member.summary: The request throttler module canceled this request to avoid DDOS.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.HTTPS_PROXY_TUNNEL_RESPONSE
member.summary: A request to create an SSL tunnel connection through the HTTPS proxy received a non-200 (OK) and non-407 (Proxy Auth) response. The response body might include a description of why the request failed.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SSL_CLIENT_AUTH_SIGNATURE_FAILED
member.summary: We were unable to sign the CertificateVerify data of an SSL client auth handshake with the client certificate's private key.
member.remarks: Possible causes for this include the user implicitly or explicitly denying access to the private key, the private key may not be valid for signing, the key may be relying on a cached handle which is no longer valid, or the CSP won't allow arbitrary data to be signed.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.MSG_TOO_BIG
member.summary: The message was too large for the transport. (for example a UDP message which exceeds size threshold).

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SPDY_SESSION_ALREADY_EXISTS
member.summary: A SPDY session already exists, and should be used instead of this connection.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.PROTOCOL_SWITCHED
member.summary: Connection was aborted for switching to another protocol. WebSocket abort SocketStream connection when alternate protocol is found.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.ADDRESS_IN_USE
member.summary: Returned when attempting to bind an address that is already in use.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SSL_HANDSHAKE_NOT_COMPLETED
member.summary: An operation failed because the SSL handshake has not completed.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SSL_BAD_PEER_PUBLIC_KEY
member.summary: SSL peer's public key is invalid.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.SSL_PINNED_KEY_NOT_IN_CERT_CHAIN
member.summary: The certificate didn't match the built-in public key pins for the host name. The pins are set in net/base/transport_security_state.cc and require that one of a set of public keys exist on the path from the leaf to the root.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CLIENT_AUTH_CERT_TYPE_UNSUPPORTED
member.summary: Server request for client certificate did not contain any types we support.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.ORIGIN_BOUND_CERT_GENERATION_TYPE_MISMATCH
member.summary: Server requested one type of cert, then requested a different type while the first was still being generated.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_COMMON_NAME_INVALID
member.summary: The server responded with a certificate whose common name did not match the host name.
member.remarks:
This could mean any of the following:
An attacker has redirected our traffic to his server and is presenting a certificate for which he knows the private key.
The server is misconfigured and responding with the wrong cert.
The user is on a wireless network and is being redirected to the network's login page.
The OS has used a DNS search suffix and the server doesn't have a certificate for the abbreviated name in the address bar.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_DATE_INVALID
member.summary: The server responded with a certificate that, by our clock, appears to either not yet be valid or to have expired.
member.remarks:
This could mean any of the following:
An attacker is presenting an old certificate for which he has managed to obtain the private key.
The server is misconfigured and is not presenting a valid cert.
Our clock is wrong.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_AUTHORITY_INVALID
member.summary: The server responded with a certificate that is signed by an authority we don't trust.
member.remarks:
This could mean any of the following:
An attacker has substituted the real certificate for a cert that contains his public key and is signed by his cousin.
The server operator has a legitimate certificate from a CA we don't know about, but should trust.
The server is presenting a self-signed certificate, providing no defense against active attackers (but foiling passive attackers).

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_CONTAINS_ERRORS
member.summary: The server responded with a certificate that contains errors. This error is not recoverable.
member.remarks:
MSDN describes this error as follows: "The SSL certificate contains errors."
It's unclear how this differs from ERR_CERT_INVALID. For consistency, use that code instead of this one from now on.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_NO_REVOCATION_MECHANISM
member.summary: The certificate has no mechanism for determining if it is revoked. In effect, this certificate cannot be revoked.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_UNABLE_TO_CHECK_REVOCATION
member.summary: Revocation information for the security certificate for this site is not available.
member.remarks:
This could mean any of the following:
An attacker has compromised the private key in the certificate and is blocking our attempt to find out that the cert was revoked.
The certificate is unrevoked, but the revocation server is busy or unavailable.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_REVOKED
member.summary: The server responded with a certificate has been revoked.
member.remarks: We have the capability to ignore this error, but it is probably not the thing to do.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_INVALID
member.summary: The server responded with a certificate that is invalid. This error is not recoverable.
member.remarks: MSDN describes this error as follows: "The SSL certificate is invalid."

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_WEAK_SIGNATURE_ALGORITHM
member.summary: The server responded with a certificate that is signed using a weak signature algorithm.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_NON_UNIQUE_NAME
member.summary: The host name specified in the certificate is not unique.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_WEAK_KEY
member.summary: The server responded with a certificate that contains a weak key (e.g. a too-small RSA key).

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.CERT_END
member.summary: The value immediately past the last certificate error code.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.INVALID_URL
member.summary: The URL is invalid.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.DISALLOWED_URL_SCHEME
member.summary: The scheme of the URL is disallowed.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.UNKNOWN_URL_SCHEME
member.summary: The scheme of the URL is unknown.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.TOO_MANY_REDIRECTS
member.summary: Attempting to load an URL resulted in too many redirects.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.UNSAFE_REDIRECT
member.summary: Attempting to load an URL resulted in an unsafe redirect (e.g., a redirect to file:// is considered unsafe).

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.UNSAFE_PORT
member.summary: Attempting to load an URL with an unsafe port number. These are port numbers that correspond to services, which are not robust to spurious input that may be constructed as a result of an allowed web construct (e.g., HTTP looks a lot like SMTP, so form submission to port 25 is denied).

member.summary: The server's response was invalid.

member.summary: machine.

member.summary: example, no KDC could be found or the principal is unknown.

member.summary: SPDY Headers have been received, but not all of them - status or version headers are missing, so we're expecting additional frames to complete them.

member.summary: The operation is not supported for this entry.

member.summary: Multiple transactions are racing to create disk cache entries. This is an internal error returned from the HttpCache to the HttpCacheTransaction that tells the transaction to restart the entry-creation logic because the state of the cache has changed.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.DNS_MALFORMED_RESPONSE

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.DNS_SERVER_REQUIRES_TCP
member.summary: DNS server requires TCP

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.NetError.DNS_SERVER_FAILED
member.summary: DNS server failed.
member.remarks:
This error is returned for all of the following error conditions:
Format error - The name server was unable to interpret the query.
Server failure - The name server was unable to process this query due to a problem with the name server.
Not Implemented - The name server does not support the requested kind of query.
Refused - The name server refuses to perform the specified operation for policy reasons.

member.summary: DNS transaction timed out.

member.summary: Failed to sort addresses according to RFC3484.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.DownloadEventArgs.Handled
member.summary: Gets or sets if the event is handled by an application.
member.remarks:
Default Handling The table below presents the way the event is handled, when is set to false (default):
Wrapper
Behavior
No default handling is provided for the windowless. If is set to false (default), the event is immediately canceled.
Technology specific WebControls.
If is set to false (default), controls will display their predefined dialog that allows the user to select the file path to save the file to.
Application Handling Applications can modally handle the by providing a response through the property, before the event handler exits.
Note that always takes precedence over . If is set to true, the request will be canceled immediately and the value of (or of any other member), is ignored.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.JavascriptMethodHandler
member.summary: Represents a method that will handle calls to one or more custom Javascript methods, synchronously.
member.param: The source of the event.
An that contains the event data.
member.returns: A encapsulating the response that will be sent to JavaScript. This can also be a with custom properties.
member.remarks:
This delegate is used with , and in DLR to tell the to create a custom method that returns a value, therefore called synchronously.
The limitations of a synchronous handler are:
You cannot make synchronous invocations from inside a synchronous handler.
You cannot pass JavaScript objects to a synchronous handler.
For more details, read:
Introduction to JavaScript Integration
Custom JavaScript Methods
A method is always called in a synchronous Javascript Execution Context (JEC). Read this article for details about Javascript Execution Contexts.
If is set to true, any value returned from a is ignored and the method call will return .
To create a method that is called asynchronously, use the delegate.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.JavascriptAsyncMethodHandler
member.summary: Represents a method that will handle calls to one or more custom Javascript methods, asynchronously.
member.param: The source of the event.
An that contains the event data.
member.remarks:
This delegate is used with , and in DLR to tell the to create a custom method that does not return a value, therefore called asynchronously.
The benefits of an asynchronous handler are:
You can make synchronous invocations from inside an asynchronous handler.
You can pass JavaScript objects to an asynchronous handler.
For more details, read:
Introduction to JavaScript Integration
Custom JavaScript Methods
A method is always called in an asynchronous Javascript Execution Context (JEC). Read this article for details about Javascript Execution Contexts.

example.code:
Option Explicit Off
Private Sub OnDocumentReady(sender As Object, e As DocumentReadyEventArgs) ' Create a global object and assign it to a dynamic object. Dim myGlobalObject As Object = DirectCast(webView.CreateGlobalJavascriptObject("myGlobalObject"), JSObject)
' Make sure we have the object. If Not myGlobalObject Then Return End If
' Create and bind a custom method dynamically. In a dynamic expression, use ' the JavascriptAsyncMethodHandler delegate to create a Javascript method ' that does not return a value and is called asynchronously. myGlobalObject.myMethod = DirectCast(AddressOf OnCustomJavascriptMethod, JavascriptAsyncMethodHandler) End Sub
' Asynchronous JavaScript method handler. Private Shared Sub OnCustomJavascriptMethod(sender As Object, e As JavascriptMethodEventArgs) Dim webView As IWebView = DirectCast(sender, IWebView)
If Not webView.IsLive Then Return End If
' Access essential objects of the web-page's current JavaScript environment. Dim global = e.Environment
' We can have the same handler handling many remote methods. ' Check here the method that is calling the handler. If e.MethodName = "myMethod" Then ' Make another synchronous call. Dim res = global.window.confirm("Called from an asynchronous handler." & vbLf & "Do you confirm?") End If End Sub

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JavascriptMethodEventArgs.MustReturnValue
member.summary: Gets if the handler is called synchronously and should provide a returned value.

remarks.note: Methods that return a value are called synchronously (the view process is blocked until the handler returns). Therefore, you cannot make synchronous invocations from inside a synchronous , as this would cause a deadlock. For the same reason, JavaScript objects cannot be passed to a that is called synchronously. Any such objects passed from JavaScript, will be replaced with undefined in the array.

summary.b: [You should no longer use this property to return a value. Instead, assign your handler as JavascriptMethodHandler or JSFunctionHandler and return the value directly from the handler.]

member.summary: Gets the unhandled exception that causes the to shutdown. This is null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if the core is shutting down in response to a normal command.
member.remarks:
The can shut down when an exception during the core's update cycle, was unhandled by user code. This will subsequently fire , before the core destroys all resources (active views and sessions) and shuts down. When this is the reason for a shut down, exposes the exception that causes the core to shut down.
Do not cancel the shutdown before you carefully investigate the exception and any inner exceptions. Report the details of the exception to: http://answers.awesomium.com.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.ShowCreatedWebViewEventArgs.NewViewInstance
member.summary: Gets the handle to the new child view, created by Awesomium.
member.remarks:
occurs when an instance creates a new child view (usually the result of window.open, clicking on a link with target="_blank" or submitting a form with target="_blank").
It is your responsibility to wrap and display this new view in your application.
The event must always be handled in your application to wrap views created by Awesomium in response to users clicking a link or JavaScript window.open calls.
If you don't handle this event, the unused web-view instance will be immediately destroyed.
There are a number of facts you need to take into consideration, before taking the appropriate actions in response to a event. The following list presents these facts and some general suggestions:
The created child view, has the same type (see ) and is assigned to the same session (see ) as its parent (opener) view. Therefore, you should not attempt to set these properties if you are wrapping the new child view with a technology specific WebControl.
In order to maintain the relationship with their parent view, child views execute and render under the same process (awesomium_process) as their parent view. If for any reason the child process crashes, all views related to it will be affected.
If is fired as a result of a Javascript window.open, will be true. In this scenario, you should always wrap the created child view instance (), to maintain the parent-child window relationship (the child page can access the parent through the window.opener property; the parent can manipulate the child through the window object returned from the window.open call, which is why window.open was most probably used in the first place).
If is fired as a result of an HTML form with target="_blank" and method="post", will be true. In this scenario, you should always wrap the created child view instance (), to allow POST data be properly passed.
When or are false, it most possibly indicates that the event is the result of a user clicking on a link with target="_blank". Since maintaining a parent-child relationship is not important in this scenario, you should cancel the event by setting to true (this tells the core to destroy the unused web-view instance), then create a new (using ) or WebControl and navigate to the provided , if any. This allows you to take advantage of the isolated process architecture of Awesomium and let each view be rendered in a separate process.
Failing to cancel the event when you are not wrapping the new child view instance, will keep the native instance alive until the is shut down. This can result in numerous unused views being spawned, but never actually used.
When or is true, navigation to the , if any, is already queued on the created child view. Therefore you should not attempt to set the when you are wrapping the child view, as this would again break the parent-child relationship (window.opener on the child page and the window object returned from the window.open call on the parent page, will be rendered invalid) or prevent passing POST data to the server respectively.
Also note that since navigation to the , if any, has already started by the moment the child view is wrapped, will not be fired for the main frame of the new instance.
Navigation to the , if any, is blocked on the created child view, when and are false. As applications will generally choose to cancel the event and create a new instance to navigate to the target URL (or even choose to navigate to the target URL on the same instance that fired the event), Awesomium.NET does this to prevent false hits to the target URL, that would have occurred by the time the event handler returns and the unused child view instance, is destroyed. What's more, users may also implement and cancel requests to new views that are the result of JavaScript window.open (see ). Therefore, if your application chooses to wrap the created child view even though it is most possibly the result of a user clicking on a link with target="_blank" or navigation to the target URL has already been canceled by an (see ), you should in this scenario only, after wrapping the child view, set the property to to resume navigation to the target URL.
Applications can occasionally choose to wrap a child view even when is false or is true, if they want to apply a single process architecture where all new views created will be rendered by the same awesomium_process.
When is true, returns a valid, initialized instance. This may be initialized to default values if is false, or reflect the specs specified to the window.open call, if is true.
If is true, applications should generally wrap and present the native view in a new popup application window. This window should have the size and location specified in , if this is not empty. They should also respect the rest of the specs available through , when creating the new application window that will host the child view.
When is true, is always also true.
will only be true, if specs were specified to the window.open call. These can be standard specs such as width=400,height=400,menubar=no, only user defined, non-standard specs such as background=black or a combination of both. These specs are available through the property.
If only user defined, non-standard specs were specified to the window.open call, will be true. In this scenario, if your application does not recognize user defined, non-standard specs, it can ignore the value of all together and wrap the new child view in a regular new application window, tab or control.
When is true, returns an array of , representing the upload data passed to the using POST.
Finally note that only an empty name parameter or a _blank target attribute specified as the name parameter in a window.open call or in a link or form, will fire a event. Other target attributes (such as _top), passed to either a window.open call, a link or a form, are handled by Awesomium internally.
Several members of , may not return valid values if Javascript is disabled. For details, read the documentation of: .
Given the facts and suggestions presented before, if your application is about to wrap the created child view, the following table shows the methods available, to wrap the created child view using any of the Awesomium.NET web-view components:
Technology
Method and Notes
Core
Pass to to wrap the new view with a .
For windowed views (see ), you should now assign a . Offscreen views have a assigned by default but depending on your application's design, you may have to assign a new by either monitoring the event, or setting the property.
Resize the to match its container.
WPF
Create a new and assign to the property.
Note that you should assign the created child view instance to , before the goes live (see ), or else the will create and wrap a new, underlying web-view instance. The appropriate way to do this, is either by binding the property in XAML (see examples in the Awesomium.NET Samples solution available with the SDK), or by monitoring the event, the last fired before the control goes live.
Resize the or its container.
Windows Forms
Create a new and assign to the property.
Note that you should assign the created child view instance to , before the goes live (see ), or else the will create and wrap a new, underlying web-view instance. The appropriate way to do this, is either by assigning the property right after the is created (see examples in the Awesomium.NET Samples solution available with the SDK),or by monitoring the event, the last fired before the control goes live.
Resize the or its container.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.ShowCreatedWebViewEventArgs.IsPopup
member.summary: Gets if this must be a popup window.
member.remarks:
This is true only when the event is the result of a Javascript window.open call ( is also true) and one or more specs have been specified to the window.open call.
The specified specs (available through the property) can be standard settings for the popup window, or only user specified specs that an application can, or cannot recognize.
For example, the following window.open calls, will both fire a with set to true:
window.open("file.html", "", "someFlag");
window.open("file.html", "", "background=black");
In the first example, the returned from , will contain a user spec in the dictionary, where the key will be someFlag and the value will be 1.
In the second example, the returned from , will contain a user spec in the dictionary, where the key will be background and the value will be black.
If the call to window.open contains only non-standard, user specs, returns true.
When and are both true, an application that does not recognize non-standard specs, can safely ignore the value of , then wrap and present the new view (see ) in a regular new window or tab, depending on the application's design.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.ShowCreatedWebViewEventArgs.IsPost
member.summary: Gets if the event is the result of an HTML form with target="_blank" and method="post".

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.ShowCreatedWebViewEventArgs.IsNavigationCanceled
member.summary: Gets if navigation to the , is already canceled to the new view ().
member.remarks:
Navigation to the , is canceled by default when is the result of links with target _blank or the submission of HTML forms with target _blank and method GET. What's more, users may also implement and cancel requests to new views that are the result of JavaScript window.open (see ).
You can still wrap the new view if is true, but you must then manually load the to the new view.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.ShowCreatedWebViewEventArgs.IsUserSpecsOnly
member.summary: Gets if the specs specified to a Javascript window.open call, contain only non-standard, user defined specs.

member.summary: Indicates if this is the main frame of the page.
member.remarks:
When a page is loaded, the main frame is usually the first to start being loaded.
If is true during a event, it indicates a new navigation. When a with set to true is not canceled, an event is fired right after, allowing you to cancel the navigation.
Note that the event is called on the I/O Thread. Therefore, you should not make any calls to instances and members that are not thread-safe.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.IWebView
member.summary: Represents a native Awesomium web-view instance. All managed web-view wrappers, implement this interface.
member.remarks:
exposes the full native web-view API, as well as .NET specific API added to web-views. It is provided for advanced coding and it allows you to override much of the .NET internal logic and call on the native web-view directly.
Note that invoking members of the interface, will still not completely bypass .NET code. However, the interface provides a property that allows you to p/invoke directly to the Awesomium native library (see ). This can be used for even more advanced scenarios, when needed.
Awesomium.NET does not officially support calling to the Awesomium library directly (either using p/invoke or even through the interface). The Awesomium team will provide no support for any issues that may occur, from using these features.
