member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.SaveImageAt(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Attempt to download an image at the specified coordinates in the page. This is meant to be used with .
member.param: An x-coordinate within an image in the page.
A y-coordinate within an image in the page.
member.remarks:
All coordinates should be localized to the view. All values are in pixels, the origin (0,0) begins at the top-left corner of the view, positive values are "down" and positive values are "right".
This method will attempt to download the image at the specified coordinates, directly from the server. In technology-specific WebControls, a Save As dialog will be shown in response to the download request.
If you are using the headless component, you will have to handle to either display a dialog or silently save the resource. More appropriately in this case, you should assign your implementation of to , to handle UI related events including .
member.returns: true if a download operation for an image at the specified coordinates, was successfully triggered; false otherwise.
member.exception: The member is called on an invalid view. (See: )

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.CreateJavascriptExecutionContext``1(Awesomium.Core.JavascriptExecutionContextMethod{``0},``0)
member.summary: Creates an asynchronousJavascript Execution Context and executes the associated with it.
member.typeparam: The type of an object that the caller can pass to the specified .
member.param: The method associated with the created Javascript Execution Context.
An object of type to be passed to the .
member.remarks:
This method creates an asynchronousJavascript Execution Context and immediately invokes the specified that is executed within the context.
The major features provided by an asynchronousJavascript Execution Context to the associated routine, are:
Easy access to essential objects of the loaded web-page's current JavaScript environment, through .
Any instance allocated within the associated either using the regular API or through dynamic expressions when using the Dynamic Language Runtime (DLR), is automatically disposed upon exiting the .
To create a copy of a that persists outside the JEC, use .
Any binding errors or other exceptions that occur within a Javascript Execution Context, are silently handled and propagated to the JavaScript console.
Most of the Javascript-related events of a view and all handlers of a custom JavaScript method, are already executed in a Javascript Execution Context.
Javascript-related events or a custom JavaScript method handlers that are called synchronously, are executed in a synchronous Javascript Execution Context. Creating an asynchronous Javascript Execution Context from within a synchronous one, is not allowed.
For details, read the following articles:
Introduction to JavaScript Integration
Javascript Execution Context
member.exception: You cannot create an asynchronous Javascript Execution Context from within a synchronous Javascript Execution Context.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.CreateJavascriptExecutionContext(Awesomium.Core.JavascriptExecutionContextMethod)
member.summary: Creates an asynchronousJavascript Execution Context and executes the associated with it.
member.param: The method associated with the created Javascript Execution Context.
member.remarks:
This method creates an asynchronousJavascript Execution Context and immediately invokes the specified that is executed within the context.
The major features provided by an asynchronousJavascript Execution Context to the associated routine, are:
Easy access to essential objects of the loaded web-page's current JavaScript environment, through .
Any instance allocated within the associated either using the regular API or through dynamic expressions when using the Dynamic Language Runtime (DLR), is automatically disposed upon exiting the .
To create a copy of a that persists outside the JEC, use .
Any binding errors or other exceptions that occur within a Javascript Execution Context, are silently handled and propagated to the JavaScript console.
Most of the Javascript-related events of a view and all handlers of a custom JavaScript method, are already executed in a Javascript Execution Context.
Javascript-related events or a custom JavaScript method handlers that are called synchronously, are executed in a synchronous Javascript Execution Context. Creating an asynchronous Javascript Execution Context from within a synchronous one, is not allowed.
For details, read the following articles:
Introduction to JavaScript Integration
Javascript Execution Context
member.exception: You cannot create an asynchronous Javascript Execution Context from within a synchronous Javascript Execution Context.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.CreateGlobalJavascriptObject(System.String)
member.summary: Create a global JavaScript object that will persist between all loaded pages, for the lifetime of this instance.
member.param: The name of the object as it will appear in JavaScript.
member.returns: If this call succeeds, the returned will be of type 'Object' (see ). You can check the reason why the call failed by calling after this method.
member.remarks:
Global Objects can only contain the following JavaScript types as properties:
Number
String
Array
Null
Other Global Objects
Undefined
Global Objects will retain any custom methods that are registered (see ).
To create a child global-object, you should specify the full name with dot-notation for example: parentObject.childObject.
The parent object should exist before attempting to make any children.
You can create global Javascript objects on a view, as soon as it goes live. ( is true). On technology specific WebControls, you should wait for the event. components go live immediately after creation.
member.exception: The member is called on an invalid view. (See: )
The operation is not supported on a Developer Tools Inspector view (see: ).
Javascript calls are not supported when Javascript is disabled (see: ).
The member is called from inside a synchronous Javascript Execution Context.
The specified is reserved. It either represents an HTML DOM object, or an object variable already available in the page. Use after , to obtain this object.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.InitializeView

member.remarks:
This is the last moment for setting any of the following properties, on a WebControl:
Technology
Properties
WPF
Windows Forms
These properties are implemented as read-write properties on WebControls and can only be set before the underlying web-view of a WebControl is created, or a previously created native view is wrapped (see ).
Right after this event is fired, the WebControl goes live ( is set to true) and these properties can no longer be changed.
Attempting to set some of the above properties after a WebControl is live, is usually silently ignored but may also throw an exception. For details, refer to the documentation of the properties.
This event is not fired on instances. A component goes live immediately at creation.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.WindowClose
member.summary: Occurs when Javascript in the page calls window.close.
member.remarks:
You can ignore this event, or respond depending on the current context. For example, if the page is open in the main window of an application or a tab, browsers display a confirmation dialog asking the user if he wants to acknowledge the page's request.
If the page is open in a popup window, browsers usually respect the request and close the popup window, without any confirmation from the user.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.JavascriptRequest
member.summary: Occurs when a JavaScript client sends a management request through (such as , etc.).
member.remarks:
The request sent is identified by .
A request token can be passed by JavaScript clients to the native application and it's received through
Unless the request originates from a page that has been created by the application (such as pages provided though a ), applications should be careful when handling management requests. For example, a command asks from the native application to exit immediately. The is provided so that native applications can validate such requests.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.JavascriptMessage
member.summary: Occurs when a JavaScript client sends a message through or .
member.remarks:
and the asynchronous , can be used instead of creating and binding to custom methods of a global JavaScript object created with .
Unlike regular synchronous custom JavaScript methods created by the managed application through or using the Dynamic Language Runtime (DLR), allows callers to pass JavaScript objects to the array, even though the method is called synchronously (see Synchronous & Asynchronous API).
JavaScript objects passed to are being serialized, any function members (methods) are stripped out and they are deserialized to the hosting application as local JSObjects. Nevertheless, the objects are still passed by reference. Any changes applied to passed objects in the handler of a event, will be reflected back to the original remote instances when returns.
Function members (methods) of objects passed to , are being stripped out when the object is passed to the hosting application (calling them from the hosting application would cause a deadlock). However this does not affect the original client-side instances.
JavaScript objects passed to , are serialized and deserialized using JSON. Objects whose structure includes a circular reference, cannot be passed.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.ShowCreatedWebView
member.summary: Occurs when an creates a new child web-view instance (usually the result of window.open or an external link).
member.remarks:
occurs when an instance creates a new child view (usually the result of window.open, clicking on a link with target="_blank" or submitting a form with target="_blank").
It is your responsibility to wrap and display this new view in your application.
The event must always be handled in your application to wrap views created by Awesomium in response to users clicking a link or JavaScript window.open calls.
If you don't handle this event, the unused web-view instance will be immediately destroyed.
There are a number of facts you need to take into consideration, before taking the appropriate actions in response to a event. The following list presents these facts and some general suggestions:
The created child view, has the same type (see ) and is assigned to the same session (see ) as its parent (opener) view. Therefore, you should not attempt to set these properties if you are wrapping the new child view with a technology specific WebControl.
In order to maintain the relationship with their parent view, child views execute and render under the same process (awesomium_process) as their parent view. If for any reason the child process crashes, all views related to it will be affected.
If is fired as a result of a Javascript window.open, will be true. In this scenario, you should always wrap the created child view instance (), to maintain the parent-child window relationship (the child page can access the parent through the window.opener property; the parent can manipulate the child through the window object returned from the window.open call, which is why window.open was most probably used in the first place).
If is fired as a result of an HTML form with target="_blank" and method="post", will be true. In this scenario, you should always wrap the created child view instance (), to allow POST data be properly passed.
When or are false, it most possibly indicates that the event is the result of a user clicking on a link with target="_blank". Since maintaining a parent-child relationship is not important in this scenario, you should cancel the event by setting to true (this tells the core to destroy the unused web-view instance), then create a new (using ) or WebControl and navigate to the provided , if any. This allows you to take advantage of the isolated process architecture of Awesomium and let each view be rendered in a separate process.
Failing to cancel the event when you are not wrapping the new child view instance, will keep the native instance alive until the is shut down. This can result in numerous unused views being spawned, but never actually used.
When or is true, navigation to the , if any, is already queued on the created child view. Therefore you should not attempt to set the when you are wrapping the child view, as this would again break the parent-child relationship (window.opener on the child page and the window object returned from the window.open call on the parent page, will be rendered invalid) or prevent passing POST data to the server respectively.
Also note that since navigation to the , if any, has already started by the moment the child view is wrapped, will not be fired for the main frame of the new instance.
Navigation to the , if any, is blocked on the created child view, when and are false. As applications will generally choose to cancel the event and create a new instance to navigate to the target URL (or even choose to navigate to the target URL on the same instance that fired the event), Awesomium.NET does this to prevent false hits to the target URL, that would have occurred by the time the event handler returns and the unused child view instance, is destroyed. What's more, users may also implement and cancel requests to new views that are the result of JavaScript window.open (see ). Therefore, if your application chooses to wrap the created child view even though it is most possibly the result of a user clicking on a link with target="_blank" or navigation to the target URL has already been canceled by an (see ), you should in this scenario only, after wrapping the child view, set the property to to resume navigation to the target URL.
Applications can occasionally choose to wrap a child view even when is false or is true, if they want to apply a single process architecture where all new views created will be rendered by the same awesomium_process.
When is true, returns a valid, initialized instance. This may be initialized to default values if is false, or reflect the specs specified to the window.open call, if is true.
If is true, applications should generally wrap and present the native view in a new popup application window. This window should have the size and location specified in , if this is not empty. They should also respect the rest of the specs available through , when creating the new application window that will host the child view.
When is true, is always also true.
will only be true, if specs were specified to the window.open call. These can be standard specs such as width=400,height=400,menubar=no, only user defined, non-standard specs such as background=black or a combination of both. These specs are available through the property.
If only user defined, non-standard specs were specified to the window.open call, will be true. In this scenario, if your application does not recognize user defined, non-standard specs, it can ignore the value of all together and wrap the new child view in a regular new application window, tab or control.
When is true, returns an array of , representing the upload data passed to the using POST.
Finally note that only an empty name parameter or a _blank target attribute specified as the name parameter in a window.open call or in a link or form, will fire a event. Other target attributes (such as _top), passed to either a window.open call, a link or a form, are handled by Awesomium internally.
Several members of , may not return valid values if Javascript is disabled. For details, read the documentation of: .
Given the facts and suggestions presented before, if your application is about to wrap the created child view, the following table shows the methods available, to wrap the created child view using any of the Awesomium.NET web-view components:
Technology
Method and Notes
Core
Pass to to wrap the new view with a .
For windowed views (see ), you should now assign a . Offscreen views have a assigned by default but depending on your application's design, you may have to assign a new by either monitoring the event, or setting the property.
Resize the to match its container.
WPF
Create a new and assign to the property.
Note that you should assign the created child view instance to , before the goes live (see ), or else the will create and wrap a new, underlying web-view instance. The appropriate way to do this, is either by binding the property in XAML (see examples in the Awesomium.NET Samples solution available with the SDK), or by monitoring the event, the last fired before the control goes live.
Resize the or its container.
Windows Forms
Create a new and assign to the property.
Note that you should assign the created child view instance to , before the goes live (see ), or else the will create and wrap a new, underlying web-view instance. The appropriate way to do this, is either by assigning the property right after the is created (see examples in the Awesomium.NET Samples solution available with the SDK),or by monitoring the event, the last fired before the control goes live.
Resize the or its container.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.IsLive
member.summary: Gets if the native web-view, is alive.
member.returns:
A value indicating if the native web-view, is alive. False indicates that the native web-view is:
Crashed (see ).
When crashed, technology specific WebControls will attempt to recreate the underlying view. For details, see: .
Prematurely destroyed (eg, using ).
Not properly instantiated. This means that something went wrong during instantiation of either the (if this is the first view created) or of the native web-view.
member.remarks:
Developers should always check this property before calling members. Trying to access the native web-view when it is not alive, can throw an .
For more details, refer to the documentation of view members.
This property also returns false when technology specific WebControls are shown in a designer. The Awesomium and the native web-view, are only instantiated during runtime.

example.code:
Private Sub ToolStripButton2_Click( sender As Object, e As EventArgs ) Handles ToolStripButton2.Click If Not m_WebControl.IsLive Then Return
m_WebControl.GoForward() End Sub

Level Title Value

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.Presenter
member.summary: Gets or sets an presentation control that will receive requests for UI related events.
member.remarks:
Members of the interface are used by views to propagate UI related requests that they cannot handle by themselves. For example, the windowless does not handle any UI related events itself. If an has been assigned to the property, those requests will be propagated to the presentation control, unless previously handled by a relative event handler.
When used with an offscreen, an instance of that also implements , will be used as the view's default surface, as long as it has been assigned to immediately after the creation of the .
Usage in WPF The interface is extensively used in WPF. presentation controls are used in the visual tree when styling a WPF . These can be custom WPF surfaces implementing (for offscreen views) or any other control providing custom presentation of a instance.
When the custom control is added to the visual tree and loaded for presentation, the instance (typically, a WPF ) uses the interface to communicate with the presentation control.
Awesomium.Windows.Controls already provides 2 such presenters:
Presentation Control Usage (by the default style)
Used when is set to (default). This is an component that uses 100% WPF logic to copy the view's pixel buffer to a bitmap that it then renders for presentation.
This is an that is used when is set to . For more details, read the documentation of .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.IsJavascriptEnabled
member.summary: Gets is Javascript is enabled on this instance.
member.remarks:
Javascript status is defined by setting the property when defining the preferences of the this view will be member of.
Javascript is enabled by default when using the default , or if no preferences or the default preferences have been specified to a custom .
Several features depend on Javascript. The following lists, present features that are not available when Javascript is disabled:
Methods
Attempting to call any of these methods when Javascript is disabled, will throw a .
Events
These events will not be fired when Javascript is disabled.
Properties
will always return false.

is ignored.

member.remarks:

Component
Method
Use .

The property is implemented as read-write property on these controls. You have to set the property before the control goes live (see ).
Either:
Set the property at design-time.
- OR -
Handle the event, the last fired before the control goes live, to set the property.
You cannot change this property on technology specific web-view controls, once they go live (see ).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.HTML
member.summary: Gets the HTML code of the currently loaded document.
member.remarks:
This property is updated after the event is fired.
This property returns null (Nothing in Visual Basic), if JavaScript is disabled in this view (see: ).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.RenderProcess
member.summary: Gets the rendering process associated with this instance. This represents the executing awesomium_process or the one specified through at initialization.
member.remarks:
This may not be initialized until some time after the view is actually created (when we receive the first IPC message from the child-process). It may also return null (Nothing in Visual Basic), is there is no rendering process associated yet (see ) or the process has crashed (see ).
The associated will be terminated when this instance is disposed and destroyed.
The default priority of the , is . This may be automatically lowered to when is false.
In a technology-specific WebControl, and the priority of the , are associated to the control's enabled status.
Actions that may corrupt the execution state of the rendering process, will directly affect view's web content rendering. Manually killing this process, will mark the view as crashed (see ).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.CreationTime
member.summary: Indicates the date and time this instance was created. If the view has not been successfully initialized, this is .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.FocusedElementType
member.summary: Gets the type of the element currently focused in the loaded page.
member.remarks:
You should generally forward keyboard events to the active instance, whenever one of the following element types are focused:
This is done automatically in technology specific WebControl instances.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.Source
member.summary: Gets or sets the URL currently presented by this instance.
member.returns: An absolute representing the URL currently loaded by this instance, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if not set or updated.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.Title
member.summary: Gets the title of the page currently loaded.
member.remarks: This property may also reflect navigation progress. For details, see .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.WebSession
member.summary: Gets the session associated with this instance.
member.remarks:
You can create a with your own preferences (see ), using . You can then use this when you create a instance, by using the function.
This property is implemented as a read-write property on technology specific WebControls. You can use the setter to specify your , right after instantiating the WebControl or at design time. You cannot change this setting after the control has been fully loaded and its underlying web-view, has been created.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.IsLoading
member.summary: Gets if any page resources are currently being loaded.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.IsCrashed
member.summary: Gets if the process of this instance, has crashed.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.IsTransparent
member.summary: Gets or sets if pages should be rendered with transparency preserved (for ex, for pages with style="background-color: transparent;")
member.remarks: When set to true, the alpha channel is premultiplied. When set to false (default), the view will have an opaque, white background.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.IsRendering
member.summary: Gets or sets if internal asynchronous rendering is currently enabled.
member.remarks:
All rendering is actually done asynchronously in a separate process and so the page is usually continuously rendering internally. You should set this to false when your surface is not rendering the view's pixel buffer (e.g., when a technology specific WebControl is not visible) to save some CPU cycles.
Technology specific WebControls usually monitor the control's visibility or enabled status and update this property automatically. They may require additional steps before you are able to set this property manually. For more details, refer to the documentation of each WebControl.
When this is false, the associated process's (see ) priority, is also automatically lowered.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.NativeWindow
member.summary: Gets the actual window handle that was created by this instance. This is only valid for windowed instances (see ).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.ParentWindow

remarks.note: When you use a , you should call this method immediately after calling . The window for this instance will not be created until you set , on the Windows platform.
Technology specific WebControls, take care of this internally. Once set and the underlying window for this instance has been created, this property cannot be changed.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.ViewType
member.summary: Gets the type of this instance.
member.remarks: For details about the various types of a instance, read the documentation of and its members, or the following article: http://wiki.awesomium.net/general-use/introduction-to-web-views.html

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.ProcessHandle
member.summary: Gets the handle for the corresponding child-process hosting this instance.
member.remarks: This may not be initialized until some time after the view is actually created (when we receive the first IPC message from the child-process).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.ProcessId
member.summary: Gets the identifier for the corresponding child-process hosting this instance.
member.remarks:
May return 0 if the instance has crashed or there is no rendering process currently associated (see ).
This is not a unique identifier for the instance. A child, rendering process can host more than one views (see ).
This does not correspond to the system-wide id of the associated (PID). It's an Awesomium-specific identifier.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.Identifier
member.summary: Gets a unique global identifier for this instance.
member.remarks:
When this instance is live (see ), this identifier is guaranteed to be unique among all instances maintained by the .
May return 0 if the instance has crashed or there is no rendering process currently associated (see ).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.SynchronousMessageTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum amount of time (in milliseconds) to wait for a response from a synchronous IPC message dispatched to the view's renderer process. Default is 800 (ms). Set this to 0 to use no timeout.
member.remarks: You should increase this if you find that a lot of your synchronous method calls keep getting (see . (Your machine just may be slow at handling IPC calls).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.Zoom
member.summary: Gets or sets the Zoom percentage for the host currently loaded.

remarks.note: Zoom amount is saved per hostname. The value of this property is automatically updated when the host currently loaded, changes (see: and ).
This operation is asynchronous: the value may not change for several milliseconds after you set this property.

member.exception: The minimum accepted value, is 1.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.IWebViewPresenter
member.summary: This interface defines the members that an presentation control should implement, if it wants to respond to UI related events, without handling the relative events.
member.remarks:
Members of the interface are used by views to propagate UI related requests that they cannot handle by themselves. For example, the windowless does not handle any UI related events itself. If an has been assigned to the property, those requests will be propagated to the presentation control, unless previously handled by a relative event handler.
When used with an offscreen, an instance of that also implements , will be used as the view's default surface, as long as it has been assigned to immediately after the creation of the .
Usage in WPF The interface is extensively used in WPF. presentation controls are used in the visual tree when styling a WPF . These can be custom WPF surfaces implementing (for offscreen views) or any other control providing custom presentation of a instance.
When the custom control is added to the visual tree and loaded for presentation, the instance (typically, a WPF ) uses the interface to communicate with the presentation control.
Awesomium.Windows.Controls already provides 2 such presenters:
Presentation Control Usage (by the default style)
Used when is set to (default). This is an component that uses 100% WPF logic to copy the view's pixel buffer to a bitmap that it then renders for presentation.
This is an that is used when is set to . For more details, read the documentation of .

member.summary: Local object.
member.remarks: Local objects can only contain properties.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.JSObjectType.Remote
member.summary: Remote object, actually stored in a remote process.
member.remarks: All API calls will be proxied to the remote process and may fail (see ).

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.JSObjectType.RemoteGlobal
member.summary: Same as except that the object will persist between all page loads.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.JSObjectType.Invalid
member.summary: Indicates that the has been disposed or that it represents an invalid instance, equivalent to .

remarks.note: Do not attempt to access members or execute any code against, or using a of type . Try to acquire a new instance through JavaScript.

member.summary: Indicates the name, target attribute and specs passed to a Javascript window.open call.
member.remarks: A valid instance of is created and is available through , when a event with set to true, is fired.

member.summary: An empty, uninitialized instance.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.op_Equality(Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs,Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs)
member.summary: Tests whether two specified instances are equivalent.
member.param: The instance that is to the left of the equality operator.
The instance that is to the right of the equality operator.
member.returns: true if and are equal; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Tests whether two specified instances are not equal.
member.param: The instance that is to the left of the inequality operator.
The instance that is to the right of the inequality operator.
member.returns: true if and are unequal; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.IsBlank
member.summary: Gets if the target attribute specified in the original window.open call, is _blank indicating that the should be loaded into a new window. The default is true.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.IsParent
member.summary: Gets if the target attribute specified in the original window.open call, is _blank indicating that the should be loaded into the parent frame. The default is false.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.IsSelf
member.summary: Gets if the target attribute specified in the original window.open call, is _blank indicating that the should replace the current page. The default is false.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.IsTop
member.summary: Gets if the target attribute specified in the original window.open call, is _blank indicating that the should replace any framesets that may be loaded. The default is false.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.UserSpecsOnly
member.summary: Gets if this contains only non-standard, user defined specs (see ).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.HasUserSpecs
member.summary: Gets if an any non-standard, user defined specs were specified.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.IgnoredSpecs
member.summary: Gets an array of specs that should be ignored.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.Name
member.summary: Gets the name of the new window, if any.
member.remarks:
If this is an empty string, the page may have specified a target attribute instead of a name for the name parameter, in the window.open call.
Only an empty name parameter or a _blank target attribute specified as the name parameter in a window.open call or on a link, will fire a event. Other target attributes (such as _top), passed to either a window.open or specified on a link, are handled by Awesomium internally.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.InitialPosition
member.summary: Gets the initial position and size, if any, indicated by the opener for the new window.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.ChannelMode
member.summary: Gets if the new window should be displayed in theater mode. The default is false.
member.remarks:
This is a non-standard flag introduced by IE, but respected by several browsers. If this is true, and return true by default, even if they have been explicitly set to false in the window.open call. For example, the instance generated for the following window.open call, will have its and properties returning true:
window.open("file.html","","location=0,toolbar=0,channelmode=1");

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.FullScreen
member.summary: Gets if the new window should be displayed in full-screen mode. The default is false.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.Location
member.summary: Gets if the new window should display the address box. The default is true.

remarks.note: The value of this property can be affected by the value of and .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.Menubar
member.summary: Gets if the new window should display the menu bar. The default is true.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.Resizable
member.summary: Gets if the new window should be resizable. The default is true.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.Scrollbars
member.summary: Gets if the new window should display scroll bars. The default is true.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.Titlebar
member.summary: Gets if the new window should display the title bar. Should be ignored unless the calling application is an HTML Application or a trusted dialog box. The default is true.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.Toolbar
member.summary: Gets if the new window should display the browser toolbar. The default is true.

remarks.note: The value of this property can be affected by the value of and .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.Status
member.summary: Gets if the new window should display a status bar. The default is true.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JSWindowOpenSpecs.UserSpecs
member.summary: Gets a list of any additional user defined, non-standard specs, specified to the window.open call. These may or may not be recognized by an application.

remarks.note:
Note that any window.open call with defined specs, will fire a event with set to true, even if the only specs specified, are user defined, non-standard specs. If your application does not recognize such specs, it should ignore the value of all together and wrap the new child view regularly.
When a event with set to true is fired, indicates if the specs passed to the window.open call, are only non-stardard, user defined specs.

member.summary: Gets if this is an empty, uninitialized instance.

member.summary: In addition to implementing the ICustomMarshaler interface, custom marshalers must implement a static method called GetInstance that accepts a String as a parameter and has a return type of ICustomMarshaler. This static method is called by the common language runtime's COM interop layer to instantiate an instance of the custom marshaler.
member.param: A cookie that the method can use to customize the returned custom marshaler.
member.returns: A instance.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.NavigationInfo
member.summary: Indicates the verbosity of navigation info.
member.remarks:
Navigation progress information is reflected to the control's :
Level Title Value
"None" only reflects the page's title, if any.
"Normal" reflects the page's title as well as "Error" and "Crashed" status.
"Verbose"
reflects progress status such as "Navigating..." and "Loading...", until the page's title is acquired. Also reflects "Error" and "Crashed" status. (Default)

member.summary: only reflects the page's title, if any.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.IResourceInterceptor
member.summary: Used to intercept requests and responses for resources.
member.remarks: Assign your to , to intercept requests for resources.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.IResourceInterceptor.OnRequest(Awesomium.Core.ResourceRequest)
member.summary: Called when a request for resources occurs. You can use this to modify requests before they are sent, respond to requests using your own custom resource-loading back-end, or to monitor requests for tracking purposes.
member.param: The resource request.
member.returns: A new (see ) to override the response; otherwise, return null (Nothing in Visual Basic) to allow normal behavior.

remarks.note: This method is called on the I/O Thread. Therefore, you should not make any calls to instances and members that are not thread-safe.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.IResourceInterceptor.OnFilterNavigation(Awesomium.Core.NavigationRequest)
member.summary: Called when a frame navigation occurs.
member.param: A instance providing information about the navigation request.
member.returns: true to cancel and block the navigation; false otherwise.

remarks.note:
This global function overrides individual services of instances. If you cancel a navigation here by returning true, and will never be called.
Navigation rules added to the of the view, will also be ignored.
This method is called on the I/O Thread. Therefore, you should not make any calls to instances and members that are not thread-safe.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.NavigationInterceptor.RaisePropertyChanged(System.String)

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.ResourceRequest.IsWindowOpen
member.summary: Gets if this is the first request sent by a new view that is the result of JavaScript window.open.
member.remarks:
The initial request () of new views that are the result of JavaScript window.open, is always issued before the event is fired.
By default, Requests that are the result of JavaScript window.open or are POST requests (such as the submission of HTML forms with method POST and target _blank), are not canceled. The user is expected to wrap the new view (see: ) when occurs, without reloading the target URL since navigation to the target URL is already queued on the new view.
In order to avoid double requests issued to a target URL, any other requests (most possibly links with target _blank or the submission of HTML forms with target _blank and method GET where data is passed through the URL therefore there's no danger of loosing data), are canceled by default, before , and the user must then load the target URL manually.
POST or window.open requests cannot be canceled in advance, as we do not know if the user chooses to wrap the new view (which is the expected behavior). This however can cause implications in certain scenarios (such as in a popup blocker scenario), where users may want to cancel such requests too.
allows you to implement an and cancel such requests yourself prior to , if you do not intend to wrap the new view at .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.ResourceRequest.IgnoreDataSources
member.summary: Gets or sets if any DataSource handlers for this request, should be ignored.
member.remarks: This is useful when you are using to override default protocols such as HTTP or FTP (see ) and you only want a subset of requests to be handled by . The request will be handled by the default handler if this request ignores the handler. This is set to false by default.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.Surface
member.summary: Represents the base class for managed surfaces.
member.remarks:
Awesomium.NET provides the base class that implements . In most scenarios, deriving is the suggested way for defining your own surface. Implementing is useful when you want to implement your surface in a class already deriving another class. What's more, Awesomium.NET already provides predefined surface implementations for most technologies.
Here's a list of predefined surfaces available with Awesomium.NET:
Technology Type
Core
WPF
WPF
Windows Forms
Windows Forms
To specify your own surface implementation (either this is an implementation or a subclass), you need to do any of the following:
Assign your surface instance to . The instance assigned, should be able to handle changes in size. In particular, is called every time the size of the view changes.
Handle the event and assign your surface to , whenever the event occurs. The event occurs every time the size of the view changes. You can assign the same surface every time, or a new one (if your implementation cannot handle resizing. All classes deriving that are available with Awesomium.NET, can handle changes in size). Each time occurs, returns the surface previously assigned to the view either through or in an earlier handling of this event, or the default surface for the view if none was previously specified. So even if you do not set when occurs, the view will keep using any previously assigned surface.
Surfaces are destroyed either manually when they are not needed or internally, when assigned to a view, when the view they are assigned to, is destroyed.

Each time occurs, returns the surface previously assigned to the view either through or in an earlier handling of this event, or the default surface for the view if none was previously specified. So even if you do not set when occurs, the view will keep using any previously assigned surface.
Surfaces are destroyed either manually when they are not needed or internally, when assigned to a view, when the view they are assigned to, is destroyed.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.ISurface.Initialize(Awesomium.Core.IWebView,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Called when the size of the view has changed and the surface needs to be re-initialized.
member.param: Indicates the view requesting the surface initialization. This is the view this instance has been assigned too. Surfaces can only be assigned to a single view at a time.
Indicates the new width of the .
Indicates the new height of the .
member.remarks:
This method is called right after , to initialize the surface. It can be called more than once, whenever the size of the view changes, if the same surface is used throughout the view's life.
This is the place where it is generally suggested that you initialize any back buffer used to copy the view's pixel buffer.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.ISurface.Paint(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,Awesomium.Core.AweRect,Awesomium.Core.AweRect)
member.summary: This method is called whenever the instance this surface is assigned to, wants to paint a certain section of the Surface with a block of pixels. It is your responsibility to copy to the location in this Surface specified by .
member.param: A pointer to a block of pixels in 32-bit BGRA format. The size of the buffer is: srcRowSpan * srcRect.Height.
The number of bytes of each row. (Usually: srcRect.Width * 4)
The dimensions of the region of to copy from. May have a non-zero origin.
The location to copy to. Always has same dimensions as but may have different origin (which specifies the offset of the section to copy to).

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.ISurface.Scroll(System.Int32,System.Int32,Awesomium.Core.AweRect)
member.summary: This method is called whenever the instance this surface is assigned to, wants to 'scroll' an existing section of the Surface by a certain offset. It your responsibility to translate the pixels within the specified clipping rectangle () by the specified offset.
member.param: The amount of pixels to offset horizontally.
The amount of pixels to offset vertically.
The rectangle that this operation should be clipped to.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.Utilities.MinifyJavascript(System.String)
member.summary: Minifies JavaScript code.
member.param: A representing the JavaScript code to minify.
member.returns: Minified, single-line JavaScript code.
member.remarks:
This is only a helper function that performs simple cleanup of JavaScript code. This function:
Removes unnecessary whitespace.
Removes comments.
Removes line breaks (turns multi-line to single-line code).
Does not remove unnecessary semicolons, brackets etc..
Does not compress the code by applying encodings.
Does not compress the code by checking the scope or semantics of variables or functions and renaming them.
This function uses compiled regular expressions and string manipulation. Though fast enough, if you use the same code multiple times in scenarios that demand maximum performance, it is suggested that you cache the minified code once in a static variable.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.JSValue
member.summary: Represents a value in Javascript.
member.remarks:
The supported data types by the Javascript interoperation API, are:
Javascript Type Managed Equivalent
Boolean
You can explicitly or implicitly cast from and to a .
Integer
You can explicitly cast from and explicitly or implicitly cast to, a .
Double
You can explicitly cast from and explicitly or implicitly cast to, a .
String
You can explicitly or implicitly cast from and to a .
Array
[]
You can explicitly cast from and explicitly or implicitly cast to, a .
Object
You can explicitly or implicitly cast from and to a .
Null
Undefined
supports explicit (and for some types, implicit) casting to and from the managed equivalent of all the supported data types. You rarely need to work with the itself. However, it can be useful if you need to check the value type before casting.

member.remarks:
The following table represents the behavior of this property, based on the JavaScript value this instance represents:
JavaScript Value
Behavior
Array
Gets or sets the member at the specified index. If the specified is out of range, the getter returns .
Object
Gets or sets the value of a property named after the specified . If no property with the specified numeric name exists, the getter returns .
String
The getter returns the character at the specified . If the specified is out of range, the getter returns . The setter has no effect on a representing a JavaScript String.
supports implicit casting to and and explicit casting to an array of . The use of this property only becomes handy when your are using the Dynamic Language Runtime (DLR) and you do not know the kind of value a certain dynamic expression returns.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.WebConfig
member.summary: Indicates configuration settings for the , during initialization.
member.remarks:
This structure is used with , to specify configuration settings for the .
The is not necessarily started immediately after you call . Actual initialization occurs when the first (see ) or instance is created. You have a last chance to edit the configuration settings when the event is fired.
You can force the to start immediately by using the overload specifying true for the start parameter. In several scenarios, this may seriously affect the auto-update feature's availability. For more information see .
These settings cannot be changed after the has started.
You can access (but not change) the configuration settings used to initialize the core after initialization, through .

member.summary: Gets or sets the file path to the log file (should include filename, for example: C:\\my_path\\out.log). This is .\\awesomium.log by default.

member.summary: Gets or sets the directory path to search for additional plugins. This is useful for bundling plugins with your application.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebConfig.ChildProcessPath
member.summary: Gets or sets the file path to the child rendering process. This is awesomium_process by default.
member.remarks:
The path specified, should be relative to the native Awesomium library (awesomium.dll), (see: ). When Awesomium.NET is deployed to the system's GAC, the path to the child process should normally be absolute.
If the specified file is not found, the will silently fall back to using .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebConfig.UserAgent
member.summary: Gets or sets the user-agent string to use instead of the default. You should only specify this if you want to spoof the user-agent.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebConfig.RemoteDebuggingPort
member.summary: Gets or sets the port that the Awesomium Inspector's HTTP server should listen on.
member.remarks:
To enable the inspector, set this value to any non-zero port (ex, 1337) and then go to http://127.0.0.1:1337 (or whatever port you specified) in some other browser.
Please note you must have inspector.pak in your working directory for the Inspector to load correctly.
Specify 0 to disable the inspector (the default).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebConfig.RemoteDebuggingHost
member.summary: The host that the Awesomium Inspector's HTTP server should bind to. The default is 127.0.0.1.
member.remarks: The default is 127.0.0.1 but it is sometimes useful to specify a different IP to bind to (especially if you are behind a router).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebConfig.ReduceMemoryUsageOnNavigation
member.summary: Gets or sets if we should automatically attempt to reduce process memory on each page navigation.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebConfig.UserScript
member.summary: User-defined JavaScript to run at the beginning of every page load. This code is run immediately after global JavaScript objects are set up and before the DOM or any inline scripts are loaded.
member.remarks:
This is not a file-path, you should pass a raw JavaScript string.
This value is global to all instances. You can specify additional script on a per-session basis via .
Use this property with extreme caution. No check for errors is performed before this code is injected to pages loading. Errors in the code defined in this property, can affect the operation of our internal JavaScript Interoperation Framework (JIF), used to keep a seamless cooperation between Awesomium.NET and the loaded page.
Among other things, JIF handles window.open, window.alert and user selections in the page.
Before using this property, please note that:
The page's full DOM is not yet created at the time this code is executed. This code is executed beforeDOMContentLoaded and .
Any global JavaScript objects (and their members) that you create with after the creation of an instance, may not be available yet, the first time a view loads a page.
Attempts to handle crucial members of the window object itself (such as window.open), may be overridden/prevented by JIF.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebConfig.CustomCSS
member.summary: User-defined CSS to be applied to all web-pages. This is useful for overriding default styles. (Default: )
member.remarks:
This is not a file-path, you should pass a raw CSS string.
This value is global to all instances. You can specify additional CSS on a per-session basis via .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebConfig.AssetProtocol
member.summary: The protocol used for loading local resources through instances. The default is: asset.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebConfig.AdditionalOptions
member.summary: Gets or sets additional command-line options for Chromium.
member.remarks:
This is for advanced users only, use this at your own risk.
Each option should be formatted as --switch=value or just --switch.

example.code: // Force native WebGL rendering. WebCore.Initialize( new WebConfig() { AdditionalOptions = new string[] { "--use-gl=desktop" } } );
' Force native WebGL rendering. WebCore.Initialize( New WebConfig() With { .AdditionalOptions = New String() { "--use-gl=desktop" } } )

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.WebCore
member.summary: Represents the core of Awesomium. It manages the creation and lifetime of all and instances and maintains useful services.
member.remarks:
The manages the creation and lifetime of all and instances and maintains useful services like:
Auto-Update
Network stack
Inter-process messaging
creation
Download operations
Generally, you should initialize the (see ) providing your custom configuration settings, before creating any views and shut it down (see ) at the end of your program.
Note that Awesomium and Awesomium.NET are not thread-safe. All API members should be called from the thread that initialized the (see ) or created the first , or technology specific WebControl if is not explicitly called. For UI applications (such as those using a technology specific WebControl) this is usually the UI thread.
Certain exceptions to this rule, such as , are documented.
If you do not initialize the , it will automatically start, using default configuration settings, when you create the first view by either calling or by instantiating a WebControl, or when you create the first .
Do not call any of the members of this class other than:
before starting the core.

member.summary: Initializes the with certain configuration settings.
member.param: An instance of specifying configuration settings.

remarks.para: This method performs lazy instantiation. The will start when the first or is created.

If you do not call this method, the will be automatically initialized using default configuration settings, when you first create a view through or by instantiating a WebControl, or when you create the first .
remarks.note:
If you are not sure if the has been initialized, check before calling this method. If is already initialized, you will have to shut it down (see ) and restart the hosting application before initializing the again.
Only a single initialization/instantiation of the is possible per application session (process).

Note that Awesomium and Awesomium.NET are not thread-safe. All API members should be called from the thread that initialized the or created the first , or technology-specific WebControl if is not explicitly called.
For UI applications (such as those using a technology specific WebControl) this is always the UI thread.
If you have started the on a non-UI thread using , you must use any of the available synchronization methods as described here.
Certain exceptions to these rules, such as , are documented.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebCore.Run
member.summary: Installs an Awesomium-specific synchronization context and starts an update loop on this thread, that will block the thread until the is shut down (see: ).
member.remarks:
This method should only be used when Awesomium is run on a dedicated, background or non-UI thread or in any environment without a valid synchronization context and without a message loop (such as a Console application).
The method will install an Awesomium-specific synchronization context and start an update loop on the thread, that will block the thread until the is shut down (see: ).
Interacting with Awesomium Cross-Thread After calling , applications can interact with Awesomium using any of the following methods:
By assigning event handlers to the various available events of the , or other components of Awesomium.NET.
Event handlers can be assigned either before you call or by using any of the rest of the methods in this list, that allow you to execute code synchronously or asynchronously on Awesomium's dedicated thread.
Event handlers will be called from Awesomium's dedicated thread. It is safe to access Awesomium API from inside those handlers but you should not attempt to access anything outside Awesomium's thread from there, unless by using similar existing synchronization methods to access those threads.
By using to asynchronously execute code on Awesomium's thread.
For details, read the Accessing Awesomium's Synchronization-Context section below.
By using to synchronously execute code on Awesomium's thread.
For details, read the Accessing Awesomium's Synchronization-Context section below.
By using any of the methods to queue work to be executed on Awesomium's thread, in the next pass.
Through the interface that is implemented by all instances.
For details, read the Thread Safety section of .
Accessing Awesomium's Synchronization-Context You can only access Awesomium's synchronization context while your code executes on Awesomium's thread. The most practical way of doing this, is by handling an event such as . Events are fired from Awesomium's thread and from your event handler you can access Awesomium's synchronization context through:
You can pass a reference to the acquired object to another thread, as long as you obtained that reference on Awesomium's main thread.
If Awesomium is running on a UI thread on MS Windows, the returned is either of type
for Windows Forms or for WPF.
If Awesomium is running on a dedicated thread and has started using , the returned is of type AwesomiumSynchronizationContext.
The simplest way to check whether you have acquired a valid synchronization context that can be used to safely execute code on Awesomium's thread, is by executing the following code on Awesomium's thread:
SynchronizationContext syncCtx = SynchronizationContext.Current; bool isValidSynchronizationContext = ( syncCtx != null ) && ( syncCtx.GetType() != typeof( SynchronizationContext ) );
Dim m_SyncCtx As SynchronizationContext = SynchronizationContext.Current Dim m_IsValidSynchronizationContext As Boolean = ( syncCtx InNot Nothing ) AndAlso ( syncCtx.GetType() <> GetType( SynchronizationContext ) )
SynchronizationContext *syncCtx = SynchronizationContext->Current; bool isValidSynchronizationContext = (syncCtx != nullptr) && (syncCtx->GetType() != SynchronizationContext::typeid);
isValidSynchronizationContext will be true if a valid synchronization object has been acquired. You can now pass this reference to other threads and use it to execute code safely on Awesomium's thread.
When can the acquired SynchronizationContext not be valid? When Awesomium is running on a UI thread or when started on a dedicated thread using , returns either or and a valid is always available.
However, if Awesomium is running on Mono or on an operating system other than MS Windows and returns , this most possibly indicates that a technology-specific synchronization model is used by the for auto-updating and a valid is not available.
In this case, you can still safely execute code on Awesomium's thread, by using any of the rest of the available methods described in Interacting with Awesomium Cross-Thread above.
Shutting Down Awesomium When your application exits, you must shut down Awesomium by calling .
is thread-safe and can be called from any thread.
Calling when Awesomium is running on a dedicated thread and has started with , will immediately exit Awesomium's update loop and uninstall Awesomium's synchronization context.
If Awesomium is running on a dedicated thread and you call from inside an event handler of any of Awesomium's events, any code in that event handler that is supposed to execute after may not be reached and executed since immediately exits and kills Awesomium's dedicated thread.
member.example:
The following samples available with the Awesomium and Awesomium .NET SDK, demonstrate starting the in a non-UI thread and interacting with it cross-thread:
BasicSample
Simple sample that demonstrates using Awesomium in a Console application and interacting with it by monitoring events.
BasicAsyncSample
Like the above, only it starts Awesomium on a dedicated thread to allow the application keep running in its own thread accepting user input. It then interacts with Awesomium using methods of the new synchronization model.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebCore.Shutdown
member.summary: Destroys the and any lingering instances.
member.remarks:
Make sure that this is not called while the hosting UI of any views created by this , is still live and visible. This method will destroy all views created by this . Any attempt to access them or any member of this class after calling this method, will fail.
When Awesomium is running on a dedicated non-UI thread using , calling will immediately exit the auto-update loop, uninstall Awesomium's synchronization context and exit the thread.
This method is thread-safe and can be called from any thread.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebCore.CreateWebSession(Awesomium.Core.WebPreferences)
member.summary: Creates an in-memory which will be used to store all user-data (such as cookies, cache, certificates, local databases, etc).
member.param: A instance specifying session specific preferences.
member.remarks:
The returned instance can be used when you create a , by either specifying it as the session parameter in , or by assigning it to the WebSession property of technology specific WebControls, when you instantiate them.
instances that share the same , share the same cookies, cache, certificates, local databases as well as the same preferences (see ).
is a disposable object. You can dispose instances that are no longer associated with a view. If you forget to do this, all instances maintained by the , are disposed at .
A session cannot not be destroyed until all instances associated with it have been destroyed, and all download operations controlled by it are either complete or canceled. Attempting to dispose a instance that is still associated with views or active download operations, will throw an exception in Awesomium.NET.
For details on how to use a , read the documentation of , or the following article: Using Web-Sessions
member.returns: Returns a new instance that you can use with any number of instances.

example.code:
Using session As WebSession = WebCore.CreateWebSession(New WebPreferences() With {.CustomCSS = "::-webkit-scrollbar { visibility: hidden; }"}) Using view As WebView = WebCore.CreateWebView(1280, 960, session) Dim finishedLoading As Boolean = False
view.LoadURL(New Uri("http://www.awesomium.com")) AddHandler view.LoadingFrameComplete, Sub(s, e) If e.IsMainFrame Then finishedLoading = True End If End Sub
Do While Not finishedLoading Thread.Sleep(100) WebCore.Update() Loop
Dim surface As BitmapSurface = CType(view.Surface, BitmapSurface) surface.SaveToPNG("result.png", True) End Using End Using

A instance specifying session specific preferences.
member.remarks:
The returned instance can be used when you create a , by either specifying it as the session parameter in , or by assigning it to the WebSession property of technology specific WebControls, when you instantiate them.
instances that share the same , share the same cookies, cache, certificates, local databases as well as the same preferences (see ).
Before you attempt to create an on-disk, you should always be sure that another session is not using the same . Only a single can use the same at a time. To check if another is currently using the specified , use:
(accessed through ).
(accessed through ).
A fast and secure way to create a new, or acquire an existing , is:
string dataPath = @"C:\SomePath"; WebSession session = WebCore.Sessions[ dataPath ] ?? WebCore.CreateWebSession( dataPath, WebPreferences.Default );
Technology specific WebSessionProviders provide existing sessions by default.
is a disposable object. You can dispose instances that are no longer associated with a view. If you forget to do this, all instances maintained by the , are disposed at . This ensures that the will be saved to disk upon application exit.
A session cannot not be destroyed until all instances associated with it have been destroyed, and all download operations controlled by it are either complete or canceled. Attempting to dispose a instance that is still associated with views or active download operations, will throw an exception in Awesomium.NET.
For details on how to use a , read the documentation of , or the following article: Using Web-Sessions

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebCore.Update
member.summary: [This method is deprecated and it will be removed in the next release. Please read the Remarks section, to see how to modify your code using new features.]
member.remarks:
Starting with version 1.7.4, Awesomium.NET supports auto-updating on non-UI threads as well.
Details
In a non-UI environment (or even in a UI application), you can now create a dedicated for Awesomium and from that thread, use to start auto-updating.
You can then interact with Awesomium from another thread using the methods described in the Interacting with Awesomium Cross-Thread section in the documentation of: .
In future versions, this method will be replaced by a synonymous event, fired on each update pass of the (similar to a Window Procedure).

member.name: E:Awesomium.Core.WebCore.ShuttingDown
member.summary: Occurs when the is shutting down.
member.remarks:
The can shut down when an exception during the core's update cycle, was unhandled by user code. This will subsequently fire , before the core destroys all resources (active views and sessions) and shuts down. When this is the reason for a shut down, exposes the exception that causes the core to shut down.
Do not cancel the shutdown before you carefully investigate the exception and any inner exceptions. Report the details of the exception to: http://answers.awesomium.com.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Core.WebCore.Download
member.summary: Occurs when a page loaded in any of the views maintained by the , requests to begin downloading a certain file.
member.remarks:
Starting with version 1.7, Awesomium.NET implements an internal download manager that takes care of downloading operations for you.
Awesomium.NET's download manager, handles with download operations at global () level, thus allowing download operations to complete even if the view that initially requested the download, is destroyed.
The event is fired for all download requests, regardless of the scenario that may be followed to handle the event.
Default Handling The table below presents the way the event is handled, when is set to false (default):
Wrapper
Behavior
No default handling is provided for the windowless. If is set to false (default), the event is immediately canceled.
Technology specific WebControls.
If is set to false (default), controls will display their predefined dialog that allows the user to select the file path to save the file to.
Application Handling Applications can modally handle the by providing a response through the property, before the event handler exits.
Note that always takes precedence over . If is set to true, the request will be canceled immediately and the value of (or of any other member), is ignored.
member.example:
The following walkthrough, better describes the two major ways of responding to, and monitoring download requests.
Default & Modal Handling
The loaded page initiates a download operation. This will immediately fire the event. The actual purpose of this event is to allow you to choose a destination path for the downloaded file.
Technology specific WebControls show a Save File dialog. If the user cancels the dialog, the download operation is canceled. You do not need to handle this event if you are using WebControls in a UI environment and you want to let Awesomium.NET take care of the download procedure. However, if your application wants to provide a silent behavior with no dialogs or wants to provide its own dialog, you should handle this event and set to true. You should then provide your own modal dialog or silently specify a destination path by setting the property, before the event handler returns.
The windowless is not related to any UI technology and is not supposed to automatically display UI of any kind. Therefore, it does not provide a default handling for the event. If you're using a , you should always handle this event to specify a destination path for the downloaded file. If you fail to do this, the event will be canceled.
If you have modally handled the event or you allowed the default dialog to be displayed and the event has not been canceled, Awesomium.NET's internal download manager goes through the following steps:
A new instance is created or, if the download operation is being repeated (see: ), the previous is retrieved.
is fired. This allows you to access the representing the download operation, in order to monitor the operation's status. is a instance (therefore it implements ). If your application uses and its items as a source to visual bindings, you do not need to handle the event.
If the event has not been canceled, and the instance represents a new download operation and not a restarted one, the instance is now added to the collection. implements . If your application uses as a source to visual bindings, you do not need to handle the event.
The operation starts (or restarts). You can monitor its status through the events of , or, in a UI application just bind settings of your visual elements to properties of the type.

member.summary: Gets if the has been initialized.
member.remarks:
The Awesomium can only be initialized once per process (see: ) and should be shut down (see: ) only when your application exits.
Once you have initialized the , this property will keep returning true even after you call and it helps you avoid re-initializing the , that is not allowed.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCore.IsRunning
member.summary: Gets if the has started automatic updating.
member.remarks:
This property returns true when the has started auto-updating, either using an available synchronization context (in UI threads), a technology or platform-specific synchronization model (in operating systems other than MS Windows), or using Awesomium's own synchronization context (when started on a non-UI thread using ).
For details, see .
This property will return false in any of the following situations:
The is not initialized yet. (see: )
On a UI thread, lazy or no explicit initialization has been performed and no instance or have been created yet, that would force initialization and start auto-updating.
On a non-UI thread, the may be initialized and or instances created, but auto-updating has not started yet by calling .
The has been shut down. (see: )
This property does not indicate if the has been initialized, but only if auto-updating has started. To check if the is already initialized and avoid re-initializing it (that is not allowed and would throw an exception), use .
will always be false when is , and true when is any other value than . Therefore it is now only provided for simplicity and its value is equal to:
bool isRunning = WebCore.UpdateState != WebCoreUpdateState.NotUpdating;
Dim isRunning As Boolean = WebCore.UpdateState <> WebCoreUpdateState.NotUpdating

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCore.IsShuttingDown
member.summary: Gets if the is currently shutting down.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCore.UpdateState
member.summary: Gets the current auto-updating state of the .
member.remarks:
Can be any of the following:
State Description
The is currently not updating. Either because it has not been started yet, or it has been shut down.
The is auto-updating using an internal background loop and an available .
This state indicates that Awesomium is running in a UI context, where a message loop exists on the thread and a valid is provided by the runtime.
This state is usually temporary and the is switched to when a technology-specific WebControl is created. However, if an application only creates components though it is a UI application, the will remain at this state.
The is running in a .NET/Mono UI technology's context and is using a technology-specific timer or synchronization model for updating.
.NET UI technologies such as WPF and Windows Forms, provide their own , synchronization model and timers. Also, when used with Mono, certain technologies do not provide a standard .NET (such as Unity, Cocoa or Gtk), but they provide their own synchronization model and timers.
Whenever possible, Awesomium takes advantage of such available models and uses them for updating the , improving performance. For example, in WPF a special is used for updating the in intervals specified at initialization (see: ) or through .
The is running on a background (non-UI) thread and is executing its own update loop.
This state is used when Awesomium has been started from a non-UI, dedicated thread that has no message loop, using .
In this state, the creates and installs an Awesomium-specific synchronization context and starts its own updating loop that updates the core in intervals specified at initialization (see: ) or through .
When in this state, the users can execute code against the Awesomium API, using any of the methods described in the Interacting with Awesomium Cross-Thread section in the documentation of: .

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.WebView
member.summary: The is similar to a tab in a browser: you can load web-pages into it, interact with it, and display it however you want.
member.remarks:
By default, a is windowless. It is your responsibility to render it on a UI or bitmap by either using any of the provided implementations, or creating your own (also see: ).
You can create a using . If you have not initialized the (see ) before creating a , the core will be initialized using default configuration settings and automatically be started before creating the view.
Unless otherwise specified, all methods are asynchronous. Each is rendered in its own child-process and most API calls are proxied through IPC messages.
Note that Awesomium and Awesomium.NET are not thread-safe. All API members should be called from the thread that initialized the (see ) or created the first , or technology specific WebControl if is not explicitly called. For UI applications (such as those using a technology specific WebControl) this is usually the UI thread.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebView.CreateGlobalJavascriptObject(System.String)
member.summary: Create a global JavaScript object that will persist between all loaded pages, for the lifetime of this instance.
member.param: The name of the object as it will appear in JavaScript.
member.returns: If this call succeeds, the returned will be of type 'Object' (see ). You can check the reason why the call failed by calling after this method.
member.remarks:
Global Objects can only contain the following JavaScript types as properties:
Number
String
Array
Null
Other Global Objects
Undefined
Global Objects will retain any custom methods that are registered (see ).
To create a child global-object, you should specify the full name with dot-notation for example: parentObject.childObject.
The parent object should exist before attempting to make any children.
You can create global Javascript objects on a view, as soon as it goes live. ( is true). On technology specific WebControls, you should wait for the event. components go live immediately after creation.

The member is called from inside a synchronous Javascript Execution Context.
The specified is reserved. It either represents an HTML DOM object, or an object variable already available in the page. Use after , to obtain this object.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebView.SaveImageAt(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Attempt to download an image at the specified coordinates in the page. This is meant to be used with .
member.param: An x-coordinate within an image in the page.
A y-coordinate within an image in the page.
member.remarks:
All coordinates should be localized to the view. All values are in pixels, the origin (0,0) begins at the top-left corner of the view, positive values are "down" and positive values are "right".
This method will attempt to download the image at the specified coordinates, directly from the server. In technology-specific WebControls, a Save As dialog will be shown in response to the download request.
If you are using the headless component, you will have to handle to either display a dialog or silently save the resource. More appropriately in this case, you should assign your implementation of to , to handle UI related events including .
member.returns: true if a download operation for an image at the specified coordinates, was successfully triggered; false otherwise.
member.exception: The member is called on an invalid view. (See: )

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebView.BeginInvoke(System.Delegate,System.Object[])
member.summary: Asynchronously executes the delegate on the thread that created this instance.
member.param: A delegate to a method to call in the context of Awesomium's thread, that takes parameters of the same number and type that are contained in the parameter.
An array of objects to pass as arguments to the specified . This parameter can be null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if the method takes no arguments.
member.returns: An interface that represents the asynchronous operation started by calling this method.
member.remarks:
The delegate is executed on Awesomium's thread during the next update pass. The delegate is called asynchronously, and this method returns immediately. You can call this method from any thread.
If you need the return value from a process started with this method, call . If you need to call the delegate synchronously, use the method instead.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebView.EndInvoke(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Waits until the process started by calling completes, and then returns the value generated by the process.
member.param: An interface that represents the asynchronous operation started by calling
member.returns: An that represents the return value generated by the asynchronous operation.
member.remarks: This method gets the return value of the asynchronous operation represented by the returned from a previous call to . If the asynchronous operation has not completed, this method will wait until the result is available.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebView.Invoke(System.Delegate,System.Object[])
member.summary: Synchronously executes the specified delegate on the thread that owns this instance, with the specified list of arguments.
member.param: A delegate to a method to call in the context of Awesomium's thread, that takes parameters of the same number and type that are contained in the parameter.
An array of objects to pass as arguments to the specified . This parameter can be null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if the method takes no arguments.
member.returns: An that represents the return value from the delegate being invoked, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if the delegate has no return value.
member.remarks:
Unlike , this method operates synchronously, that is, it waits until the process completes before returning. Exceptions raised during the call are propagated back to the caller.
Use this method when you want to access members from a different thread than the thread that created the view, to marshal the call to Awesomium's thread.
