member.summary: Gets if the process of this instance, is currently responsive.

member.summary: Gets a providing information about the current selection range.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.FocusedElementType
member.summary: Gets the type of the element currently focused in the loaded page.
member.remarks:
You should generally forward keyboard events to the active instance, whenever one of the following element types are focused:
This is done automatically in technology specific WebControl instances.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.ToolTipText
member.summary: Gets the tool-tip text currently indicated by the web-view, usually as a result of hovering over elements in the page.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.ParentView
member.summary: Gets the parent view (if any) of this instance.
member.remarks:
A can only have a parent if it is a popup view that was created by Awesomium in response to a Javascript window.open.
For more details, see .
Be careful when you access members of the parent instance. The parent may have been destroyed while the this (child) view, is still alive. Always check before accessing members on the parent view, to avoid exceptions.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.LatestContextData
member.summary: Gets the latest web-view context data, usually updated by a right-click in page.
member.returns: A that represents the latest web-view context data.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.TerminationStatus
member.summary: Gets the termination status of this instance.
member.remarks: This is if the web-view has not been instantiated yet (this can be the case in a technology specific WebControl) and if the web-view process has not been terminated and is still running.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.ProcessId
member.summary: Gets the identifier for the corresponding child-process hosting this instance.
member.remarks:
May return 0 if the instance has crashed or there is no rendering process currently associated (see ).
This is not a unique identifier for the instance. A child, rendering process can host more than one views (see ).
This does not correspond to the system-wide id of the associated (PID). It's an Awesomium-specific identifier.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.Identifier
member.summary: Gets a unique global identifier for this instance.
member.remarks:
When this instance is live (see ), this identifier is guaranteed to be unique among all instances maintained by the .
May return 0 if the instance has crashed or there is no rendering process currently associated (see ).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.IsRendering
member.summary: Gets or sets if internal asynchronous rendering is currently enabled.
member.remarks:
All rendering is actually done asynchronously in a separate process and so the page is usually continuously rendering internally. You should set this to false when your surface is not rendering the view's pixel buffer (e.g., when a technology specific WebControl is not visible) to save some CPU cycles.
Technology specific WebControls usually monitor the control's visibility or enabled status and update this property automatically. They may require additional steps before you are able to set this property manually. For more details, refer to the documentation of each WebControl.
When this is false, the associated process's (see ) priority, is also automatically lowered.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.Presenter
member.summary: Gets or sets an presentation control that will receive requests for UI related events.
member.remarks:
Members of the interface are used by views to propagate UI related requests that they cannot handle by themselves. For example, the windowless does not handle any UI related events itself. If an has been assigned to the property, those requests will be propagated to the presentation control, unless previously handled by a relative event handler.
When used with an offscreen, an instance of that also implements , will be used as the view's default surface, as long as it has been assigned to immediately after the creation of the .
Usage in WPF The interface is extensively used in WPF. presentation controls are used in the visual tree when styling a WPF . These can be custom WPF surfaces implementing (for offscreen views) or any other control providing custom presentation of a instance.
When the custom control is added to the visual tree and loaded for presentation, the instance (typically, a WPF ) uses the interface to communicate with the presentation control.
Awesomium.Windows.Controls already provides 2 such presenters:
Presentation Control Usage (by the default style)
Used when is set to (default). This is an component that uses 100% WPF logic to copy the view's pixel buffer to a bitmap that it then renders for presentation.
This is an that is used when is set to . For more details, read the documentation of .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.InvokeRequired
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the caller must call an invoke method when making method calls to the view because the caller is on a different thread than the one the view was created on.
member.remarks:
Awesomium is not thread-safe. This property determines whether you must call or when making method calls to members of an instance. This is the case if Awesomium is running on a dedicated thread (see: ), or if Awesomium is running on a UI thread and you are trying to access members of an instance for a different thread.
When using Awesomium with Mono in an operating system other than MS Windows, the provided may not be safe for cross-thread calls to Awesomium.
Awesomium's implementation of , does not rely on the current thread's and can be used to make cross-thread calls to Awesomium API, in any operating system and technology.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.IsLive
member.summary: Gets if the native web-view, is alive.
member.returns:
A value indicating if the native web-view, is alive. False indicates that the native web-view is:
Crashed (see ).
When crashed, technology specific WebControls will attempt to recreate the underlying view. For details, see: .
Prematurely destroyed (eg, using ).
Not properly instantiated. This means that something went wrong during instantiation of either the (if this is the first view created) or of the native web-view.
member.remarks:
Developers should always check this property before calling members. Trying to access the native web-view when it is not alive, can throw an .
For more details, refer to the documentation of view members.
This property also returns false when technology specific WebControls are shown in a designer. The Awesomium and the native web-view, are only instantiated during runtime.

example.code:
Private Sub ToolStripButton2_Click( sender As Object, e As EventArgs ) Handles ToolStripButton2.Click If Not m_WebControl.IsLive Then Return
m_WebControl.GoForward() End Sub

member.summary: Occurs when Javascript in the page calls window.close.
member.remarks:

If the page is open in a popup window, browsers usually respect the request and close the popup window, without any confirmation from the user.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Core.WebView.JavascriptRequest
member.summary: Occurs when a JavaScript client sends a management request through (such as , etc.).
member.remarks:
The request sent is identified by .
A request token can be passed by JavaScript clients to the native application and it's received through
Unless the request originates from a page that has been created by the application (such as pages provided though a ), applications should be careful when handling management requests. For example, a command asks from the native application to exit immediately. The is provided so that native applications can validate such requests.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Core.WebView.JavascriptMessage
member.summary: Occurs when a JavaScript client sends a message through or .
member.remarks:
and the asynchronous , can be used instead of creating and binding to custom methods of a global JavaScript object created with .
Unlike regular synchronous custom JavaScript methods created by the managed application through or using the Dynamic Language Runtime (DLR), allows callers to pass JavaScript objects to the array, even though the method is called synchronously (see Synchronous & Asynchronous API).
JavaScript objects passed to are being serialized, any function members (methods) are stripped out and they are deserialized to the hosting application as local JSObjects. Nevertheless, the objects are still passed by reference. Any changes applied to passed objects in the handler of a event, will be reflected back to the original remote instances when returns.
Function members (methods) of objects passed to , are being stripped out when the object is passed to the hosting application (calling them from the hosting application would cause a deadlock). However this does not affect the original client-side instances.
JavaScript objects passed to , are serialized and deserialized using JSON. Objects whose structure includes a circular reference, cannot be passed.

member.name: E:Awesomium.Core.WebView.ShowCreatedWebView
member.summary: Occurs when an creates a new child web-view instance (usually the result of window.open or an external link).
member.remarks:
occurs when an instance creates a new child view (usually the result of window.open, clicking on a link with target="_blank" or submitting a form with target="_blank").
It is your responsibility to wrap and display this new view in your application.
The event must always be handled in your application to wrap views created by Awesomium in response to users clicking a link or JavaScript window.open calls.
If you don't handle this event, the unused web-view instance will be immediately destroyed.
There are a number of facts you need to take into consideration, before taking the appropriate actions in response to a event. The following list presents these facts and some general suggestions:
The created child view, has the same type (see ) and is assigned to the same session (see ) as its parent (opener) view. Therefore, you should not attempt to set these properties if you are wrapping the new child view with a technology specific WebControl.
In order to maintain the relationship with their parent view, child views execute and render under the same process (awesomium_process) as their parent view. If for any reason the child process crashes, all views related to it will be affected.
If is fired as a result of a Javascript window.open, will be true. In this scenario, you should always wrap the created child view instance (), to maintain the parent-child window relationship (the child page can access the parent through the window.opener property; the parent can manipulate the child through the window object returned from the window.open call, which is why window.open was most probably used in the first place).
If is fired as a result of an HTML form with target="_blank" and method="post", will be true. In this scenario, you should always wrap the created child view instance (), to allow POST data be properly passed.
When or are false, it most possibly indicates that the event is the result of a user clicking on a link with target="_blank". Since maintaining a parent-child relationship is not important in this scenario, you should cancel the event by setting to true (this tells the core to destroy the unused web-view instance), then create a new (using ) or WebControl and navigate to the provided , if any. This allows you to take advantage of the isolated process architecture of Awesomium and let each view be rendered in a separate process.
Failing to cancel the event when you are not wrapping the new child view instance, will keep the native instance alive until the is shut down. This can result in numerous unused views being spawned, but never actually used.
When or is true, navigation to the , if any, is already queued on the created child view. Therefore you should not attempt to set the when you are wrapping the child view, as this would again break the parent-child relationship (window.opener on the child page and the window object returned from the window.open call on the parent page, will be rendered invalid) or prevent passing POST data to the server respectively.
Also note that since navigation to the , if any, has already started by the moment the child view is wrapped, will not be fired for the main frame of the new instance.
Navigation to the , if any, is blocked on the created child view, when and are false. As applications will generally choose to cancel the event and create a new instance to navigate to the target URL (or even choose to navigate to the target URL on the same instance that fired the event), Awesomium.NET does this to prevent false hits to the target URL, that would have occurred by the time the event handler returns and the unused child view instance, is destroyed. What's more, users may also implement and cancel requests to new views that are the result of JavaScript window.open (see ). Therefore, if your application chooses to wrap the created child view even though it is most possibly the result of a user clicking on a link with target="_blank" or navigation to the target URL has already been canceled by an (see ), you should in this scenario only, after wrapping the child view, set the property to to resume navigation to the target URL.
Applications can occasionally choose to wrap a child view even when is false or is true, if they want to apply a single process architecture where all new views created will be rendered by the same awesomium_process.
When is true, returns a valid, initialized instance. This may be initialized to default values if is false, or reflect the specs specified to the window.open call, if is true.
If is true, applications should generally wrap and present the native view in a new popup application window. This window should have the size and location specified in , if this is not empty. They should also respect the rest of the specs available through , when creating the new application window that will host the child view.
When is true, is always also true.
will only be true, if specs were specified to the window.open call. These can be standard specs such as width=400,height=400,menubar=no, only user defined, non-standard specs such as background=black or a combination of both. These specs are available through the property.
If only user defined, non-standard specs were specified to the window.open call, will be true. In this scenario, if your application does not recognize user defined, non-standard specs, it can ignore the value of all together and wrap the new child view in a regular new application window, tab or control.
When is true, returns an array of , representing the upload data passed to the using POST.
Finally note that only an empty name parameter or a _blank target attribute specified as the name parameter in a window.open call or in a link or form, will fire a event. Other target attributes (such as _top), passed to either a window.open call, a link or a form, are handled by Awesomium internally.
Several members of , may not return valid values if Javascript is disabled. For details, read the documentation of: .
Given the facts and suggestions presented before, if your application is about to wrap the created child view, the following table shows the methods available, to wrap the created child view using any of the Awesomium.NET web-view components:
Technology
Method and Notes
Core
Pass to to wrap the new view with a .
For windowed views (see ), you should now assign a . Offscreen views have a assigned by default but depending on your application's design, you may have to assign a new by either monitoring the event, or setting the property.
Resize the to match its container.
WPF
Create a new and assign to the property.
Note that you should assign the created child view instance to , before the goes live (see ), or else the will create and wrap a new, underlying web-view instance. The appropriate way to do this, is either by binding the property in XAML (see examples in the Awesomium.NET Samples solution available with the SDK), or by monitoring the event, the last fired before the control goes live.
Resize the or its container.
Windows Forms
Create a new and assign to the property.
Note that you should assign the created child view instance to , before the goes live (see ), or else the will create and wrap a new, underlying web-view instance. The appropriate way to do this, is either by assigning the property right after the is created (see examples in the Awesomium.NET Samples solution available with the SDK),or by monitoring the event, the last fired before the control goes live.
Resize the or its container.

member.summary: Occurs when the page requests to display a drop-down (popup) menu. This is usually the result of a user clicking on a select HTML input element.
member.remarks:
By default, technology specific WebControls provide their own drop-down (popup) menus. If you wish to prevent the control from displaying its own menu and handle the event yourself, set to true and then use any of the following methods to respond to the view:
These members are not directly available through the predefined wrappers. You will have to cast the wrapper to , to access these members.
Optionally, you can easily cancel or select an item by using: or .
The windowless , does not provide any internal implementation for drop-down (popup) menus. If you are using a instance with your UI application, you will have to handle the event yourself. Technology specific Awesomium.NET assemblies, provide predefined drop-down (popup) menu controls that you can use with your WPF or Windows Forms application.
Note that always takes precedence over . If is set to true, the request will be canceled immediately and the value of (or any other member), is ignored.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebPreferences.CustomCSS
member.summary: User-defined CSS to be applied to all web-pages. This is useful for overriding default styles. (Default: )
member.remarks:
This is not a file-path, you should pass a raw CSS string.
This value is concatenated with the global .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebPreferences.UserScript
member.summary: User-defined JavaScript to run at the beginning of every page load. This code is run immediately after global JavaScript objects are set up and before the DOM or any inline scripts are loaded.
member.remarks:
This is not a file-path, you should pass a raw JavaScript string.
This value is concatenated with the global .
Use this property with extreme caution. No check for errors is performed before this code is injected to pages loading. Errors in the code defined in this property, can affect the operation of our internal JavaScript Interoperation Framework (JIF), used to keep a seamless cooperation between Awesomium.NET and the loaded page.
Among other things, JIF handles window.open, window.alert and user selections in the page.
Before using this property, please note that:
The page's full DOM is not yet created at the time this code is executed. This code is executed beforeDOMContentLoaded and .
Any global JavaScript objects (and their members) that you create with after the creation of an instance, may not be available yet, the first time a view loads a page.
Attempts to handle crucial members of the window object itself (such as window.open), may be overridden/prevented by JIF.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebPreferences.ProxyConfig
member.summary: Indicates the proxy settings for all network requests. Specify "none" to disable all proxy use, specify "auto" to attempt to detect the proxy using system settings (e.g., via the Internet Properties dialog on Windows or the Network panel of System Preferences on Mac OSX). Specify anything else to set manual proxy settings.
member.example:
Possible values can be:
Value Description
"none" No proxy. (Default).
"auto" Detect system proxy settings.
"http=myproxy:80;ftp=myproxy2"
Use HTTP proxy "myproxy:80" for http:// URLs, and HTTP proxy "myproxy2:80" for ftp:// URLs.
"myproxy:80" Use HTTP proxy "foopy:80" for all URLs.
"socks4://myproxy" Use SOCKS v4 proxy "foopy:1080" for all URLs.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.WebSession
member.summary: Represents a session responsible for storing all user-generated data (cookies, cache, authentication, etc.). It can either be purely in-memory or saved to disk.
member.remarks:
instances that share the same , share the same cookies, cache, certificates, local databases as well as the same preferences (see ).
Due to being responsible for maintaining authentication contexts, instances are also responsible for controlling download operations that are then maintained by the . This is why a cannot be released while a download operation initiated by a view associated with it, is in progress.
Assigning a WebSession The following table presents the various ways of assigning a to an instance, depending on the technology:
Technology
Methods
Core ()
Create a using .
Assign the session to a new during instantiation (see ).
WPF ()
Assign a to the WPF by using a in XAML. For an example, see: Using Web-Sessions
Assign a to the WPF programmatically, by using the property.
The session must be assigned to the control before the control goes live (see ), usually in the container's constructor, right after InitializeComponent or by handling the event.
Windows Forms ()
Assign a to the Windows Forms by using a in XAML. For an example, see: Using Web-Sessions
Assign a to the WPF programmatically, by using the property.
The session must be assigned to the control before the control goes live (see ), usually in the container's constructor, right after InitializeComponent or by handling the event.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebSession.ReservedAssetHosts
member.summary: A list of asset host names that are reserved by Awesomium.NET for internal use, and they cannot be used with .

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebSession.Dispose
member.summary: Releases this instance.
member.remarks:
You can dispose instances that are no longer associated with a view. If you forget to do this, all instances maintained by the , are disposed at . This ensures that the will be saved to disk upon application exit.
A session cannot not be destroyed until all instances associated with it have been destroyed and all download operations controlled by this session, are either complete or canceled.
member.exception: Cannot dispose a that is assigned to active views or controls active download operations. Make sure that no view and no download operation is using this session before disposing it.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebSession.AddDataSource(System.String,Awesomium.Core.Data.DataSource)
member.summary: Adds a instance for a specified host.
member.param: The host to bind to the added . For example, if myhost is specified, a resource file named myimage.png must be requested using: asset://myhost/myimage.png.
The instance that will handle requests for local assets.
member.remarks:
A instance is responsible for providing local assets when code (HTML or Javascript) from a page asks for them. The default protocol for requesting local assets is: asset://.
To choose the name of the protocol yourself, explicitly initialize the (see: ) setting .
This scenario allows you to override standard protocols (such as http://), or use DataSources to handle protocols that are not handled by default (such as ftp:// and mailto://).
member.exception: This instance has either been disposed or never properly initialized.
An empty string or null reference has been specified for .
A null reference has been specified for .
The specified , has been disposed.
The specified , is assigned to another . A can only be used by a single session.
The specified is reserved by Awesomium.NET, for internal use. For a list of reserved asset host names, see .

member.exception: This instance has either been disposed or never properly initialized.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebSession.SetCookie(System.Uri,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets a cookie for a certain URL asynchronously.
member.param: The URL to set the cookie on.
The cookie string, for example: "key1=value1; key2=value2"
Specifies if this cookie is HTTP-only.
Specifies if this is a session cookie. (Will not be saved to disk)

remarks.note: Note that this method is asynchronous. What's more, on on-disk sessions (see: ), even if the page or server set a cookie, this is not guaranteed to be persisted on-disk immediately. Session data (including cookies) remain most of the time in-memory for performance reasons and are not persisted to disk until the session is released (either at or ).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebSession.HasViews
member.summary: Gets if this is currently assigned to instances.
member.remarks:
You can access the views this session is associated with, through the property.
A session cannot be destroyed until all instances associated with it have been destroyed. You should always check this property before attempting to call . A session may still have associated views, even if returns an empty array. This is because disposed views are asynchronously destroyed.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebSession.Views
member.summary: Gets the instances that share this .

remarks.note: A session cannot be destroyed until all instances associated with it have been destroyed. You should always check before attempting to call . A session may still have associated views, even if this property returns an empty array. This is because disposed views are asynchronously destroyed.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebSession.HasDownloads
member.summary: Gets if this is currently controlling active download operations.
member.remarks:
You can access the download operations controlled by this session, through the property.
A session cannot be destroyed until all download operations controlled by this session, are either complete or canceled. You should always check this property before attempting to call .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebSession.ActiveDownloads

member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumSTATDATA
member.summary: The IEnumSTATDATA interface is used to enumerate through an array of STATDATA structures, which contain advisory connection information for a data object. IEnumSTATDATA has the same methods as all enumerator interfaces: Next, Skip, Reset, and Clone.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumSTATDATA.Next(System.Int32,Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.STATDATA[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Retrieves the next celt items in the enumeration sequence. If there are fewer than the requested number of elements left in the sequence, it retrieves the remaining elements. The number of elements actually retrieved is returned through pceltFetched (unless the caller passed in NULL for that parameter).

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumSTATDATA.Skip(System.Int32)
member.summary: Skips over the next specified number of elements in the enumeration sequence.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumSTATDATA.Reset
member.summary: Resets the enumeration sequence to the beginning.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumSTATDATA.Clone(Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumSTATDATA@)
member.summary: Creates another enumerator that contains the same enumeration state as the current one. Using this function, a client can record a particular point in the enumeration sequence and then return to that point at a later time. The new enumerator supports the same interface as the original one.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumFORMATETC
member.summary: The IEnumFORMATETC interface is used to enumerate an array of FORMATETC structures. IEnumFORMATETC has the same methods as all enumerator interfaces: Next, Skip, Reset, and Clone.

The number of elements actually retrieved is returned through pceltFetched (unless the caller passed in NULL for that parameter).

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumFORMATETC.Skip(System.Int32)
member.summary: Skips over the next specified number of elements in the enumeration sequence.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumFORMATETC.Reset
member.summary: Resets the enumeration sequence to the beginning.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumFORMATETC.Clone(Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumFORMATETC@)
member.summary: Creates another enumerator that contains the same enumeration state as the current one. Using this function, a client can record a particular point in the enumeration sequence and then return to that point at a later time. The new enumerator supports the same interface as the original one.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IAdviseSink
member.summary: The IAdviseSink interface enables containers and other objects to receive notifications of data changes, view changes, and compound-document changes occurring in objects of interest. Container applications, for example, require such notifications to keep cached presentations of their linked and embedded objects up-to-date. Calls to IAdviseSink methods are asynchronous, so the call is sent and then the next instruction is executed without waiting for the call's return.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IAdviseSink.OnDataChange(Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.FORMATETC@,Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.STGMEDIUM@)
member.summary: Called by the server to notify a data object's currently registered advise sinks that data in the object has changed.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IAdviseSink.OnViewChange(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Notifies an object's registered advise sinks that its view has changed.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IAdviseSink.OnRename(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Called by the server to notify all registered advisory sinks that the object has been renamed.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IAdviseSink.OnSave
member.summary: Called by the server to notify all registered advisory sinks that the object has been saved.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IAdviseSink.OnClose
member.summary: Called by the server to notify all registered advisory sinks that the object has changed from the running to the loaded state.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IDataObject
member.summary: The IDataObject interface specifies methods that enable data transfer and notification of changes in data. Data transfer methods specify the format of the transferred data along with the medium through which the data is to be transferred. Optionally, the data can be rendered for a specific target device. In addition to methods for retrieving and storing data, the IDataObject interface specifies methods for enumerating available formats and managing connections to advisory sinks for handling change notifications.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IDataObject.GetData(Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.FORMATETC@,Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.STGMEDIUM@)
member.summary: Called by a data consumer to obtain data from a source data object. The GetData method renders the data described in the specified FORMATETC structure and transfers it through the specified STGMEDIUM structure. The caller then assumes responsibility for releasing the STGMEDIUM structure.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IDataObject.GetDataHere(Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.FORMATETC@,Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.STGMEDIUM@)
member.summary: Called by a data consumer to obtain data from a source data object. This method differs from the GetData method in that the caller must allocate and free the specified storage medium.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IDataObject.QueryGetData(Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.FORMATETC@)
member.summary: Determines whether the data object is capable of rendering the data described in the FORMATETC structure. Objects attempting a paste or drop operation can call this method before calling IDataObject::GetData to get an indication of whether the operation may be successful.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IDataObject.GetCanonicalFormatEtc(Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.FORMATETC@,Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.FORMATETC@)
member.summary: Provides a standard FORMATETC structure that is logically equivalent to one that is more complex. You use this method to determine whether two different FORMATETC structures would return the same data, removing the need for duplicate rendering.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IDataObject.SetData(Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.FORMATETC@,Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.STGMEDIUM@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called by an object containing a data source to transfer data to the object that implements this method.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IDataObject.EnumFormatEtc(Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.DATADIR)
member.summary: Creates an object for enumerating the FORMATETC structures for a data object. These structures are used in calls to IDataObject::GetData or IDataObject::SetData.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IDataObject.DAdvise(Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.FORMATETC@,Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.ADVF,Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IAdviseSink,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Called by an object supporting an advise sink to create a connection between a data object and the advise sink. This enables the advise sink to be notified of changes in the data of the object.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IDataObject.DUnadvise(System.Int32)
member.summary: Destroys a notification connection that had been previously set up.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IDataObject.EnumDAdvise(Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IEnumSTATDATA@)
member.summary: Creates an object that can be used to enumerate the current advisory connections.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.SynchronousWindowPosition
member.summary: If the calling thread and the thread that owns the window are attached to different input queues, the system posts the request to the thread that owns the window. This prevents the calling thread from blocking its execution while other threads process the request.
member.remarks: SWP_ASYNCWINDOWPOS

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.DeferErase
member.summary: Prevents generation of the WM_SYNCPAINT message.
member.remarks: SWP_DEFERERASE

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.DrawFrame
member.summary: Draws a frame (defined in the window's class description) around the window.
member.remarks: SWP_DRAWFRAME

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.FrameChanged
member.summary: Applies new frame styles set using the SetWindowLong function. Sends a WM_NCCALCSIZE message to the window, even if the window's size is not being changed. If this flag is not specified, WM_NCCALCSIZE is sent only when the window's size is being changed.
member.remarks: SWP_FRAMECHANGED

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.HideWindow
member.summary: Hides the window.
member.remarks: SWP_HIDEWINDOW

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotActivate
member.summary: Does not activate the window. If this flag is not set, the window is activated and moved to the top of either the topmost or non-topmost group (depending on the setting of the hWndInsertAfter parameter).
member.remarks: SWP_NOACTIVATE

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotCopyBits
member.summary: Discards the entire contents of the client area. If this flag is not specified, the valid contents of the client area are saved and copied back into the client area after the window is sized or repositioned.
member.remarks: SWP_NOCOPYBITS

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.IgnoreMove
member.summary: Retains the current position (ignores X and Y parameters).
member.remarks: SWP_NOMOVE

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotChangeOwnerZOrder
member.summary: Does not change the owner window's position in the Z order.
member.remarks: SWP_NOOWNERZORDER

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotRedraw
member.summary: Does not redraw changes. If this flag is set, no repainting of any kind occurs. This applies to the client area, the nonclient area (including the title bar and scroll bars), and any part of the parent window uncovered as a result of the window being moved. When this flag is set, the application must explicitly invalidate or redraw any parts of the window and parent window that need redrawing.
member.remarks: SWP_NOREDRAW

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotReposition
member.summary: Same as the SWP_NOOWNERZORDER flag.
member.remarks: SWP_NOREPOSITION

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotSendChangingEvent
member.summary: Prevents the window from receiving the WM_WINDOWPOSCHANGING message.
member.remarks: SWP_NOSENDCHANGING

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.IgnoreResize
member.summary: Retains the current size (ignores the cx and cy parameters).
member.remarks: SWP_NOSIZE

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.IgnoreZOrder
member.summary: Retains the current Z order (ignores the hWndInsertAfter parameter).
member.remarks: SWP_NOZORDER

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.SetWindowPosFlags.ShowWindow
member.summary: Displays the window.
member.remarks: SWP_SHOWWINDOW

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IShellFolder.CompareIDs(System.Int32,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Determines the relative order of two file objects or folders, given their item identifier lists. Return value: If this method is successful, the CODE field of the HRESULT contains one of the following values (the code can be retrived using the helper function GetHResultCode): Negative A negative return value indicates that the first item should precede the second (pidl1 < pidl2). A positive return value indicates that the first item should follow the second (pidl1 > pidl2). Zero A return value of zero indicates that the two items are the same (pidl1 = pidl2).
member.param: Value that specifies how the comparison should be performed. The lower Sixteen bits of lParam define the sorting rule. The upper sixteen bits of lParam are used for flags that modify the sorting rule. values can be from the SHCIDS enum
Pointer to the first item's ITEMIDLIST structure.
Pointer to the second item's ITEMIDLIST structure.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.WinAPI.IExtractIcon.Extract(System.String,System.UInt32,System.IntPtr@,System.IntPtr@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Extracts an icon image from the specified location.
member.param: A pointer to a null-terminated string that specifies the icon location.

A pointer to an HICON value that receives the handle to the small icon. This parameter may be NULL.

The desired size of the icon, in pixels. The low word contains the size of the large icon, and the high word contains the size of the small icon. The size specified can be the width or height. The width of an icon always equals its height.
member.returns: Returns S_OK if the function extracted the icon, or S_FALSE if the calling application should extract the icon.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.ComStream
member.summary: Wraps an IStream interface pointer from COM into a form consumable by .Net.
member.remarks: This implementation is immutable, though it's possible that the underlying stream can be changed in another context.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ComStream.#ctor(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.IStream@)
member.summary: Wraps a native IStream interface into a CLR Stream subclass.
member.param: The stream that this object wraps.
member.remarks: Note that the parameter is passed by ref. On successful creation it is zeroed out to the caller. This object becomes responsible for the lifetime management of the wrapped IStream.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream
member.summary: Wraps a managed stream instance into an interface pointer consumable by COM.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ManagedIStream class with the specified managed Stream object.
member.param: The stream that this IStream reference is wrapping.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.Clone(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.IStream@)
member.summary: Creates a new stream object with its own seek pointer that references the same bytes as the original stream.
member.param: When this method returns, contains the new stream object. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::Clone in the MSDN library. This class doesn't implement Clone. A COMException is thrown if it is used.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.Commit(System.Int32)
member.summary: Ensures that any changes made to a stream object that is open in transacted mode are reflected in the parent storage.
member.param: A value that controls how the changes for the stream object are committed.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::Commit in the MSDN library.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.CopyTo(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.IStream,System.Int64,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Copies a specified number of bytes from the current seek pointer in the stream to the current seek pointer in another stream.
member.param: A reference to the destination stream.
The number of bytes to copy from the source stream.
On successful return, contains the actual number of bytes read from the source. (Note the native signature is to a ULARGE_INTEGER*, so 64 bits are written to this parameter on success.)
On successful return, contains the actual number of bytes written to the destination. (Note the native signature is to a ULARGE_INTEGER*, so 64 bits are written to this parameter on success.)

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.LockRegion(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Restricts access to a specified range of bytes in the stream.
member.param: The byte offset for the beginning of the range.
The length of the range, in bytes, to restrict.
The requested restrictions on accessing the range.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::LockRegion in the MSDN library. This class doesn't implement LockRegion. A COMException is thrown if it is used.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Reads a specified number of bytes from the stream object into memory starting at the current seek pointer.
member.param: When this method returns, contains the data read from the stream. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
The number of bytes to read from the stream object.
A pointer to a ULONG variable that receives the actual number of bytes read from the stream object.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for ISequentialStream::Read in the MSDN library.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.Revert
member.summary: Discards all changes that have been made to a transacted stream since the last Commit call.
member.remarks: This class doesn't implement Revert. A COMException is thrown if it is used.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.Seek(System.Int64,System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Changes the seek pointer to a new location relative to the beginning of the stream, to the end of the stream, or to the current seek pointer.
member.param: The displacement to add to dwOrigin.
The origin of the seek. The origin can be the beginning of the file, the current seek pointer, or the end of the file.

On successful return, contains the offset of the seek pointer from the beginning of the stream. (Note the native signature is to a ULARGE_INTEGER*, so 64 bits are written to this parameter on success.)
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::Seek in the MSDN library.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.SetSize(System.Int64)
member.summary: Changes the size of the stream object.
member.param: The new size of the stream as a number of bytes.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::SetSize in the MSDN library.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.Stat(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.STATSTG@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the STATSTG structure for this stream.
member.param: When this method returns, contains a STATSTG structure that describes this stream object. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
Members in the STATSTG structure that this method does not return, thus saving some memory allocation operations.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.UnlockRegion(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the access restriction on a range of bytes previously restricted with the LockRegion method.
member.param: The byte offset for the beginning of the range.
The length, in bytes, of the range to restrict.
The access restrictions previously placed on the range.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::UnlockRegion in the MSDN library. This class doesn't implement UnlockRegion. A COMException is thrown if it is used.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Writes a specified number of bytes into the stream object starting at the current seek pointer.
member.param: The buffer to write this stream to.
The number of bytes to write to the stream.
On successful return, contains the actual number of bytes written to the stream object. If the caller sets this pointer to null, this method does not provide the actual number of bytes written.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.ManagedIStream.Dispose
member.summary: Releases resources controlled by this object.
member.remarks: Dispose can be called multiple times, but trying to use the object after it has been disposed will generally throw ObjectDisposedExceptions.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.SafeMILHandle.#ctor
member.summary: Use this constructor if the handle isn't ready yet and later set the handle with SetHandle. SafeMILHandle owns the release of the handle.
member.SecurityNote: Critical: This derives from a class that has a link demand and inheritance demand TreatAsSafe: Ok to call constructor

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.SafeMILHandle.#ctor(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Use this constructor if the handle exists at construction time. SafeMILHandle owns the release of the parameter.
member.SecurityNote: Critical: This derives from a class that has a link demand and inheritance demand

member.name: M:Awesomium.Windows.SafeMILHandle.ReleaseHandle
member.SecurityNote: Critical - calls unmanaged code, not treat as safe because you must validate that handle is a valid COM object.
